loans.name: Victoria Zenina's Group

texts.es:
Victoria, Adaliz and Apolonia are members of the Comunal Spring Bank. They have different stories: Apolonia sells sweets in the center of the city of Ayacucho, she started this business 35 years ago when she was very young, Adaliz sells groceries out of her house and on Sundays she sells new and used shoes at the San Juan Bautista market. And Victoria sells clothes upon request and offering them to her friends and family, she started her business 6 years ago. The loans are of 1600 soles, 1200 soles and 600 soles, that will be invested in the purchase of cookies, chocolates, cigarettes, gum, new and used shoes, rice, sugar, soft drinks, milk, noodles, and kids clothing. They hope to better their businesses day to day and have more goals like going to the markets and having a shoe factory. Their dreams are to have their own shoe store and that their children finish their studies and become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Victoria, Adaliz y Apolonia son integrantes del Banco Comunal Primavera. Ellas tienen diferentes negocios: Apolonia venD. golosinas en el centro D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho, este negocio lo realiza hace 35 años desD. que era muy joven, Adaliz venD. abarrotes en su casa y los días domingos venD. zapatos usados y nuevos en la feria D. San Juan Bautista y Victoria venD. ropa a pedido y ofreciendo a sus amigas y familiares, negocio que realiza desD. hace 6 años. Sus préstamos son D. 1600 soles, 1200 soles y 600 soles, que invertirán en la compra D. galletas, chocolates, cigarro, chicles, zapatos nuevos y usados, arroz, azúcar, gaseosa, leche, fideo, chompas, ropa D. bebe. Ellas esperan mejorar su negocio día a día y tienen más metas como ir a las ferias y tener una fabrica D. zapatos. Sus sueños son tener una tienda propia D. zapatos, tener una zapatería y que sus hijas terminen sus estudios y sean profesionales.

loans.use: The loans are of 1600 soles, 1200 soles and 600 soles, that would be invested in the purchase of cookies, chocolates, cigarettes, gums, new and used shoes, rice, sugar, soft drinks, milk, noodles, and baby clothing.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es:
Sra. Maribel M. B. is 37 years old and is originally from the city of Bluefields. She is married to Sr. Alfredo Castillo, and they have two children in primary school. Sra. M. has 8 years of experience as owner of a shop selling cheese and cream. Her clients are heads of families and stores offering services in the home. It is notable that in this city a significant amount of cheese and cream are consumed. For this reason, Sra. M. needs to pruchase 204 pounds of cheese at a cost of $1.00 per pound, and 120 pounds of cream at a cost of $0.80 per pound. This investment should be enough to satisfy the demand of her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Maribel M. B. tiene 37 años de edad, es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefields, esta casada con el Sr. Alfredo Castillo tienen 2 hijos ambos estudian en la primaria. La Sra. M. tiene 8 años de experiencia es propietaria de un tramo donde vende queso y crema, sus clientes son padres de familia y pulperías que la prefieren por brindar un servicio a domicilio. Se debe mencionar que en esta ciudad se consume bastante queso y crema por esa razón la Sra. M. necesita comprar 204 libras de queso que cuesta $ 1.00 dólar la libra y 120 libras de crema que cuesta $0.80 centavos dólar la libra, con esta inversión podrá abastecer la demanda de las pulperías.

loans.use: Purchase of Cheese and Cream

loans.name: Lourdes Akihito

texts.es:
Mrs. Lourdes is a member of the Banco Comunal las Activas community bank, and lives in the Calleria district of Ucayali. She is 33 years old and has three children. Her husband is a driver, but his income is not enough to cover their living expenses. For this reason, with her first loan of $100USD from Manuela Ramos, she decided to open a small beauty parlor.

Currently, she has a small establishment where she cuts and colors hair, gives manicures and perms, etc. Her main customers are children, given that she exudes charisma while performing her services.

With the current loan, to be repaid over a period of five months, she will expand her business location and purchase additional supplies such as mirrors, an electric trimmer and other basics needed to run the salon such as scissors, talc and hair creams. Lourdes is very happy to have three healthy children and to have been able to move along with her business. Thanks to her endeavor she will be able to continue to help with her childrens’ educational expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Lourdes pertenece al Banco Comunal las Activas, vive en el Asentamiento Humano Santa Rosa - ubicado en Jr. Virgen Maria Mz D Lt. 06, del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 33 años de edad y es madre de 3 hijos, su esposo es motocarrista, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos de casa, es así que Lourdes, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decide poner una pequeña peluquería. En la actualidad cuenta con un pequeño establecimiento de corte de cabello, maniquiure, tintes, ondulados, etc. Sus principales clientes son los niños dado que tiene carisma para atenderlos. Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,200, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, ampliará el local de su negocio y comprará 2 espejos, 1 maquina para cortar pelo y otros insumos necesarios para desarrollar su actividad (2 tijeras , 1 talco, 5 cremas para pelo y 3 botellas de ácido). Lourdes está muy contenta de tener a sus tres hijos sanos y haber logrado encaminar su negocio. Gracias a su negocio podrá seguir aportando en los gastos de estudios de sus hijos.

loans.use: Expand business location and purchase beauty salon supplies such as mirrors, hair trimmers and other supplies.

loans.name: Marnia Fermina

texts.es:
Sra. Marnia Fermina B. is 31 years old, and is originally from the city of Bluefields. She is the single mother of 4 children who attend primary and secondary school. Sra. B. has 5 years of experience as owner of a meat market where she sells pork and beef. Her clients are restaurant owners and heads of households. It is notable that this month a significant amount of pork is consumed for the Christmas holidays. For this reason, Sra. B. needs to purchase 400 pounds of pork at a cost of $0.75 per pound. This investment should be enough to cover the demand of her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Marnia Fermina B. tiene 31 años de edad, es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefields, es madre soltera de 4 hijos que estudian en la primaria y secundaria. La Sra. B. tiene 5 años de experiencia, es propietaria de una carnicería donde vende carne de cerdo y de res. Sus clientes son los dueños de comedores y padres de familia. Cabe mencionar que en este mes se consume bastante la carne de cerdo para las fiestas navideñas por esa razón la Sra. B. necesita comprar 400 libras de carne de cerdo que cuesta $ 0.75 centavo dólar la libra, con esta inversión podrá abastecer la demanda de los dueños de comedores y de los padres de familia.

loans.use: Purchase of 400 lbs. of pork

loans.name: Yessenia

texts.es:
Señora Yessenia began her business 8 years ago with a startup amount of C$200.00, contributed by her husband. This gave her the opportunity to start her business, to continue forward and to help support her three children in their studies, nutrition and health care.

Currently she has obtained a space in the central market near the edge of the meat section. Little by little her business has grown with loans from CEPROD. that have been a vital strongpoint for the growth of her business, and have helped her increase her inventory.

Señora Yessenia has achieved better living conditions in her home, as her business generates sufficient income to give her family improved conditions, thanks to the financial assistance she has received from her friends at CEPROD., who are always there to give a hand to their clients. It is notable that she has had 10 loans in 2 years.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Yessenia inicio su negocio hace 8 años con un monto inicial de C$200.00 producto D. aporte D. esposo, teniendo la oportunidad de comenzar con su negocio que le ayudaria a salir adelante y ayudarse al mantenimiento de sus 3 hijos en sus estudios, alimentacion y salud

Actualmente ha logrado adquirir un tramo en el mercado central en el sector de ventas de carne a la orilla D. anden. Poco a poco a crecido con los creditos de ceproD. que ha sido el punto de apoyo vital para su crecimiento en su negocio y que le ha ayudado a crecer en su inventario.

Ha logrado adquirir mejores condiciones de vida en el hogar ya que su negocio le genera suficientes utilidades para darle a su familia mejores condiciones gracias a la ayuda que recibi de su financiera amiga CeproD. que siempre va de la mano con el cliente. Cabe señalar que ha tenido 10 creditos en 2 años .

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: María

texts.es:
Mrs. Maria belongs to the community bank “Las Fresitas”, is 65 years old and has one grown son who is her pride and joy. With the first loan of $100USD from Manuela Ramos, she invested in the sale of beef.

Currently, she has a small location in the “Yarina Cocha” market and she gets up very early to prepare breakfast and then go to her place in the market to take care of her many customers. In the afternoon she does embroidery and takes care of her young grandson.

With the recent loan of approximately $1003USD from Manuela Ramos, to be repaid over a period of six months, she will invest in items such as beef and kitchen utensils.

Maria, despite family problems, has never felt defeated. On the contrary, she told us that neither age nor the obstacles that can come along in life should impede the realization of one’s dreams. These challenges should instead give us the motivation we need to make our goals a reality.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Fresitas”, Jr. 3 de Octubre 262, distrito de Yarina Cocha D. departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 65 años y es madre de 1 hijo mayor de edad y que es el orgullo de ella. Con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 (US$100) decide invertir en la venta de carne de res. En la actualidad tiene un pequeño puesto en el mercado de Yarina Cocha y se levanta muy temprano para preparar el desayuno y después ir a su puesto en el mercado y atender a sus clientes que por cierto son muchos, en las tardes se dedica a hacer bordados y cuidar a su pequeño nieto. Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 3,000 (US$ 1003.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará S/. 200.00 en carne de res, implementos de cocina (2 cuchillos, un hacha, 1 ciento de bolsas para la entrega de la carne), además dará mantenimiento a su balanza. María, a pesar de tener problemas familiares no se ha sentido vencida, muy por el contrario, nos contó que la edad y los obstáculos que se puedan presentar en la vida no son impedimentos para realizar nuestros sueños, nos da el impulso que necesitamos algunas veces para sentirnos capaces de realizar nuestros objetivos.

loans.use: Purchase beef and kitchen utensils.

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Sra. D. A. sells typical Nicaraguan food starting very early in the morning. She has done this work for 25 years, starting with capital of only C$50.00 cordobas.

This activity has allowed her to raise her three children as a single mother. She has sought to sustain her family through this business.

She initially maintained her business through loans from CEPRODEL, who helped her to develop the business. She has paid back 5 loans, and has an excellent credit record.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. D. A. se dedica a la venta de comida tipica nicaraguense desde muy tempranas horas, dedicandose a esta actividad desde hace 25 años , iniciando con un capital de C$50.00 cordobas.

Esta actividad le ha permitido el criar a sus tres pequños hijos, siendo madre soltera busca el sustento de su familia por medio de esta actividad.>p> Inicialmente para mantener su negocio ha prestado a Ceprodel quien le ha ayudado en el desarrollo de su negocio en el cual ya ha cancelado 5 creditos con un ecelente record de credito..

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Dora

texts.es:
Dora looks after her convenience store in a kind and courteous way every day of the week. She knows how to gain her clients' confidence, and they all think that she is a model of optimism and overcoming. She started to work because she needed to as she had a 10 year old son and her husband left her. However, this did not make her give up her animated spirit which has allowed her to keep going with this business which now satisfies the needs of her home. As her son grows she would like to have more financial stability, and it is for this reason that she would like to enlarge her business, buying some window displays and getting in some more products. Let's help this young mother in her noble work.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Dora, atiende su tienda de venta de abarrotes de manera muy amable y cortés, todos lo días de la semana, con un carisma muy grande ella a sabido ganarse la confianza de todos sus clientes, quienes al observarla concluyen en que es un ejemplo de superación y optimismo.Se inició en las labores comerciales debido a la gran necesidad que tenia, en compañía de su hijo de diez años ya que su esposo la abandonó dejándola sola al cuidado de este pequeño, sin embargo este panorama difícil no hizo decaer el ánimo de superación de Dora por lo cual a costa de mucho esfuerzo logró tener este negocio que hoy la ayuda enormemente a satisfacer las necesidades de su hogar.Así mismo sabe que a medida que su hijo crezca tendrá mayores requerimientos económicos por lo que desea ampliar desde ya su negocio con estos fines, comprando algunas vitrinas y surtiendo de manera más diversa su local.Apoyemos a esta joven madre en su noble labor.

loans.use: To fit out the small store so that it can make more money quickly/Implementación del pequeño negocio para lograr su consolidación en poco tiempo.

loans.name: Eusebio

texts.es:
Eusebio is a an extremely experienced and diligent man, who is very well trained in agriculture which is a field he has been a part of for his whole life. He dedicated himself to this activity when he was very little, thanks to the enthusiasm that his parents instilled in him. It's with much effort that he is able to grow mangos and plantains, which he subsequently sells to wholesalers who bring his products to all the markets in his region. The development of these activities allows him to educate and adequately maintain his six children who are grateful for his effort and sacrifice. Today at 60 years of age, he continues to be an enterprising man who wants to make his way into more competitive markets with his fruit products; for that to happen he needs a substantial increase in investment and he appeals to your generous hearts. The help that he receives is very important and indispensable to ensure a noble end to the life of this working man.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Drejet, Kiva volunteer.

Eusebio, es un hombre sumamente experimentado y diligente, muy bien adiestrado en las labores agrícolas que durante toda su vida fueron parte de é, ya que se dedicó a esta actividad desde muy pequeño gracias al ánimo que sus padres inyectaban en él, es así que con mucho esfuerzo logra producir mangos y plátanos que posteriormente vende a comerciantes mayoristas que llevan sus productos a todos los mercados de su región. El desarrollo de estas actividades le permitieron educar y mantener adecuadamente a sus seis hijos quienes agradecen su esfuerzo y sacrificio. Hoy a sus 60 años el sigue siendo un hombre emprendedor por lo cual desea abrirse paso en mercados más competitivos a través de sus productos frutícolas; para ello necesita una mejora muy sustancial en la inversión que realiza y apela a vuestros corazones generosos ya que la ayuda que reciba es muy importante e imprescindible para este fin tan noble en la vida de este hombre trabajador.

loans.use: Raise capital to increase his production

loans.name: Lucila

texts.es:
Lucila is a mother, who in time, has been able to have a small store to sell her products after they’ve been harvested. Thanks to the little space she’s been able to have in her home, she was able to seed her vegetables more frequently and give them their respective care and attention without interfering with the care and attention she gives to her children, who are still young and require her presence and care. Today she’d like to expand her store and buy some tools for work to enable her to better the variety of her products. She’s hoping to receive a loan to make her dreams a reality and make her business prosper. With your help, she can do it.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

. Lucila, es una madre que con el transcurso del tiempo ha logrado tener un pequeño depósito para seleccionar sus productos luego de sus cosechas y gracias al espacio que pudo tener en su hogar, inicio la siembra de sus productos de manera más frecuente y en mayor cantidad a los cuales les dedica el respectivo cuidado y atención, sin descuidar también el cuidado y atención de sus hijos, quienes por ser aún pequeños requieren de su cariño y compañía.Hoy desea y añora ampliar aún más su depósito y comprar algunos instrumentos de trabajo que le permitirán mejorar la selección de sus productos.Solicita un préstamo para concretar sus anhelos y hacer próspero su negocio, con su apoyo podrá lograrlo.

loans.use: To increase the products in her store and to buy tools to better the variety of her products.

loans.name: Livio

texts.es:
Livio is a man who sacrificed a lot to open a little store in his house. He is now starting to make plans with his wife to establish a small restaurant where the people and visitors of his town can taste the delicious flavors of his wife’s cooking. Thanks to this dream, they can wake up with enthusiasm and get to work on formalizing their restaurant in no time. Today his one-year old son needs lots of care, but if the work is shared, the load is less, and counting on your support, it will be a lot less. Help this entrepreneurial family with the loan it’s soliciting to begin putting its dream in motion.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

. Livio, un hombre que a base de mucho sacrificio aperturó una tiendita en su domicilio y donde hoy empieza con su esposa a proyectarse y trabajar arduamente con el propósito de establecer un pequeño restaurante donde los pobladores y visitantes de su pequeño pueblito puedan degustar de la exquisita sazón de su esposa.Gracias a estas sueños pueden despertarse con gran entusiasmo y trabajar en diversas labores para formalizar en poco tiempo su restaurante. Hoy su hijo de un año requiere de muchos cuidados, pero si el trabajo es compartido es menos la carga y contando con su apoyo aún será menor. Ayude a esta emprendedora familia con la suma que solicita para poner en marcha sus sueños.

loans.use: To start a small restaurant offering home-style cooking.

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Elena is a woman, who despite the hardships she’d had to face, showed herself to be strong in the face of adversity. Despite her fortitude, it took all her strength and one thought…to not let her self break under the circumstances. Thanks to that thought, she was able to recuperate after not only an operation she had two years ago, but also being abandoned by her husband. Today she shows all women that, yes, it’s possible thanks to the promise she made to herself to get better and leave behind the bad times. She now has a vulcanizer and a motorized car, which generate her principal income. But, even so, she needs your support to start a small restaurant of home-style cooking, in her home. Let’s collaborate with her so she can make her dreams a reality.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

Elena, es una mujer que a pesar de las duras pruebas que tuvo que enfrentar siempre se mostró resistente frente a las adversidades, a pesar de su inmensa entereza salió de ellas con mucho esfuerzo con un solo pensamiento de no dejarse doblegar por las circunstancias y gracias a este pensamiento, también se viene recuperando de la operación que tuvo que realizarse hace dos años y del abandono de su pareja.Hoy demostró a todas las mujeres que si se puede y gracias al empeño que puso para recuperarse y dejar atrás estos malos momentos tiene un vulcanizadota y un motocarro los cuales generan y son su principal fuente de ingreso económico, aún así requiere de tu apoyo y solicita, ya que tiene el propósito de de implementar en casa un pequeño restaurante de comida típica.Colaboremos con su petición para que pronto pueda convertir en realidad sus anhelos.

loans.use: To start a small restaurant business in her home.

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
Maruja is a happy woman despite her husband having abandoned her with her her little boy in her arms; she knew she had to move forward. Thanks to the help of family members it wasn’t so hard to overcome this difficult stage of her life and she began a business selling groceries in her town. Her happiness was contagious and her neighbors became her most loyal customers, with whom she can always count on and to whom she serves without abandon. Despite counting on a number of good people, she would like to increase her business and knows that you could be one of those good people. She is sure she will receive support to put her project in motion and to forge a promising future for her little one and not ever be in need of the man who abandoned her.

Translated from Spanish by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

Doña Maruja, es una alegre dama que a pesar del abandono de su esposo y quedándose con su hijo pequeño en brazos tuvo que salir adelante; gracias al apoyo de sus familiares no le fue tan difícil superar esta dura etapa de su vida y empezó un gran negocio de venta de abarrotes en su comunidad y su alegría contagió a sus vecinos los cuales se volvieron en sus más abnegados clientes con los cuales puede contar siempre y trata de servir incansablemente.A pesar de contar con un sin número de buenas personas desea incrementar su negocio y sabe que una de esas grandes personas puede ser usted y está segura de recibir vuestro apoyo para poner en marcha su proyecto a fin de forjar un futuro prometedor para su pequeño y no necesitar nunca del hombre desconsiderado que la abandonó.

loans.use: To buy food supplies and a variety of basic items.

loans.name: Mujeres Jereh - Group 1

texts.en:
Manuela lives with her husband and three children in the neighborhood of La Pina, in the outskirts of Santo Domingo. Over the past several years she has started a business for herself where she makes and sells cloth curtains (which often serve as makeshift doors in homes throughout the Dominican Republic), sheets, and comforters. She is asking for her first loan so that she can buy better quality fabric and a few new patterns of fabrics from which she will make her sheets, curtains and comforters.

She says her goal is to improve her business step-by-step and to watch it continue to grow “more and more as each day passes.” Her dream is to see her children become educated professionals and to live a life of healthy decisions and love. Personally, she says she strives to always be a good, honest, and hardworking person.

Manuela wants to thank everyone who is supporting her with this loan, and she says that “if at any time you need anything, she is your friend, and her doors are open.”

NOTE: This is a group loan. Manuela is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of the loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: To buy better quality fabric and a few new patterns of fabrics.

loans.name: Damiana

texts.en:
Damiana is a single mom who works hard and fights hard to raise four children in a small home outside of Santo Domingo. She started a candle-making business several years ago, and it has undoubtedly been a huge success. In her neighborhood, the power goes out several times a day, so small, affordable candles sell very well.

As her reputation started to grow, people began to ask her if she made or sold specialized types of candles. She realized she could make more profit if she was able to meet this demand. She is asking for her first loan so that she can buy a few different dyes and fragrances to put into her waxes. She plans to add this scented and colored wax to new molds. As we visited with her, she showed us the prototype of a star-shaped votive that smelled of fresh lemons.

She says that her family members' lives have started to improve as her business began to grow. She knows that, with this loan and hard work, they will continue to work towards a brighter future.

loans.use: To purchase dyes and fragrances for her candle-making business

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina lives with her husband, three children, and grandson in their small home on the outskirts of Santo Domingo. From her home, she sells used and new clothes, undergarments, shoes, and occasionally cuts hair. She is asking for her first loan from Esperanza International so that she can buy new products to offer her community; specifically, she is thinking of buying clothes that are more fashionable, new hair products, and a few beauty products.

Georgina says it is her goal to keep growing her business, expanding it, and advancing. She says that it is important to have an objective in life and to keep fighting, and it is for that reason that she has always worked so hard and will continue to work hard.

Her dream is to one day be able to not only help her children become educated and comfortable, but to also help the poor in Africa. She says she has read about the poverty and disease there and says there is much to be done in the world. Georgina says that although she cannot help much, what she can do, she does. She says that most importantly, she thanks God everyday for the gifts that she has been blessed with. She is most thankful to everyone who is interested in helping her grow her business.

loans.use: To buy new products to offer her community, such as clothes that are more fashionable, new hair products, and a few beauty products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To further improve the image of her business and to provide better service for her clients

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more food ingredients and further expand her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To redecorate her beauty salon and to further expand her line of beauty products and supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To continue growing her business by selling breakfast and milk shakes made with fresh fruits.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more kitchen supplies at wholesale price

loans.name: Arshad

texts.en: I am Arshad B.. I live in the small semi-urban town of Raiwind in Pakistan. I am married and have two boys. I live with my family in a one-room brick house. I am not educated, but I am aware of the importance of education. I have enrolled my elder son in kindergarten, but the other boy is too young to attend school yet. My husband uses his vehicle to provide public transportation. His vehicle needs maintenance and few spare parts. This is our only source of income. Please help us and lend us $225 for this purpose.

loans.use: Vehicle repair

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en: I am Parveen B.. I am married and have five children, all of whom attend a local school. I live with my family in the small town Raiwind, Pakistan. My husband works at a factory for low wages, and I sell milk from my house. I would like  to buy another cow to increase production and increase my income. Please lend me $200.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en: I am Zainab B.. I was born and brought up in Okara but moved to the small town Raiwind three years ago. I live here with my husband and three sons in a rented house. My husband is a contract daily wage laborer who works for meager wages. He also sells milk to supplement our small income. He would like buy another cow in order to increase his income. Please lend us $225 for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Zahida

texts.en:
My name is Zahida B.. I have two girls. My elder daughter is in kindergarten. My younger daughter is not of school age yet. I live with my family in a mud house in Raiwind, a small semi-urban town in Pakistan.
My husband is a daily wage laborer who polishes tile floors. I sew clothes for women in my neighborhood and sell milk from my house to increase our household income. I need a loan of $225 to buy another cow for my business. I hope to give my children a secure financial future.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Munnawer

texts.en: I am Munnawer B. from the small town of Raiwind, Pakistan. I am married and have six children,  four boys and two girls. We live in a small two-room brick house. My husband deals in livestock, and my son runs a small corner stand where he sells soft drinks and cigarettes. He would like to increase the inventory he sells there, and we are asking  for a loan of $350.

loans.use: Buy inventory for a soft-drink stand

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
I am asking for a loan of $175 for my embroidery business. I started embroidering clothes to order for my neighbors, two years ago, after my marriage. I started this business because my husband’s income was very small. With this loan I intend to buy an embroidery machine. I hope that this machine will increase my profits, and that I will be able to give my only child a better future.

Safia B.

loans.use: To buy an embroidery machine

loans.name: Seema

texts.en: I am Seema B.. I am married have seven children: three boys and four girls. I live with my family in a small brick house in Raiwind, a town known in Pakistan for its dairy production.   My husband deals in livestock to make a living. He buys and sells cows, goats, and sheep. We would like to expand our business and request a loan of $200. With this loan my husband plans to buy few sheep and goats.

loans.use: To buy sheep and goats

loans.name: Rasheeda

texts.en: I am Rasheeda B.. I live in the small semi-urban town of Raiwind, Pakistan. I am married and have six children: four boys and two girls. My husband works at a local company that pays very low wages. To increase our household income, one of my sons started selling milk. He started this business with a loan we took out earlier. He would like to buy an additional cow for his business. Please lend us $350.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Hameedan

texts.en: My name is Hameedan B.. I am married and  live with my family in a brick house in Raiwind, a small town in Pakistan. I have three boys. The two older boys attend school;  the youngest is not of school age yet. My husband is an electrician, and I sell milk from my house. I need to buy another cow for my business, for which I would like a loan of $350.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Cacilda Fernando

texts.pt:
Cacilda Fernando D. was born in Checua, Manhiça. She is 50 years old, married, and the mother of 6 children. She took out her first loan for 5,000 MT on November 28, 2006, to support her business. She sells food products such as pasta, eggs, oil, sugar, etc., from her home. In this second phase Cacilda is asking for 12,000 MT, to be paid in 7 months.

Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva Volunteer.

Cacilda Fernando D. , Potadora do Bi nº 110951254J, Natural de Checua/ Manhiça, residente no bairro da polana caniço Quarteirão nº67 casa 24, de 50 anos de Idade, mãe de 6 filhos vivendo maritalmente ,entrou no projecto a 28/11/06 tomando o valor de 5000 mt para o seu negocio , vende produtos alimentares como, Massa, ovos, oleo açucar,etc, esta no 2º ciclo vai tomar 12000 mt para pagar em 7 meses tem o seu negocio na sua residencia.

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Ni Komang Wirani

texts.id:
Ni Komang Wirani has gained lots of experience raising pigs over the last several years. From the beginning of her business she has raised male pigs, but because that has only produced enough income to barely cover operational costs. Expanding her business to include raising sows will allow her to better meet the needs of her family. By purchasing one breeding-age sow for the price of 800,000 Rupiah, within six months she believes she can earn 2,500,000 Rupiah from selling the 10 piglets the sow produces. With the income she makes from selling the piglets, she will be able to send her three children to school and their family can move out of a semi-permanent home into their own house. Ni Komang Wirani's husband works at a minimum wage job and also feels this undertaking would be beneficial to their family. He plans to help her handle the business when he is not at work. She would like to go forward with her idea for this big undertaking, but she is limited by a lack of capita because this type of business takes time to produce a profit. This is why she would like to borrow capital to purchase a breeding-age sow and the feed it will need. She is very optimistic that her business will take off because she will be able to afford to raise more sows as her income increases.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Pengalaman menjalankan usaha beternak babi selama beberapa tahun membuat Ni Komang Wirani semakin pintar dalam mengelola usahanya ini. Pada awalnya hanya memelihara penggemukan saja, tetapi karena hasil yang diperolehnya tidak maksimal dan hanya cukup untuk menutupi biaya opersional usahanya saja, maka Ni Komang Wirani berinisiatif memelihara penginduk. Dengan memelihara penginduk hasil yang diperoleh- nya dirasa bisa mencukupi kebutuhan keluarga. Seekor penginduk yang dibeli dengan harga Rp. 800.000,- dalam waktu enam bulan bisa menghasilkan Rp. 2.500.000,- lewat 10 ekor anak yang dilahirkannya, sehingga ke tiga oraing anaknyapun bisa bersekolah dan mereka bisa tinggal dalam rumah yang cukup nyaman walaupun belum bisa dikatakan bagus karena masih semi permanen. Suaminya yang hanya pegawai kecil dengan gaji minim juga merasakan manfaat dari usaha beternak ini dan ikut membantu Ni Komang Wirani dalam mengelola usahanya di sela-sela waktu luangnya. Memliki usaha yang besar dan maju adalah angan-angannya tetapi terhambat oleh terbatasnya modal yang dimiliki sehingga usahanya tidak bisa berkembang dengan cepat. Itulah sebabnya saat mendapat pinjaman modal usaha dari DINARI, Ni Nyoman Wirani semakin optimis usahanya bisa berkembang karena jumlah penginduk yang dipeliharanya bisa ditambah sehingga hasilnyapun bisa meningkat.

loans.use: for purchasing sows and feed

loans.name: Ni Nengah Tayu

texts.id:
Ni Nengah Tayu is a housewife who is very good at taking care of her family. Not only does she does she raise her children, but she also fulfills her obligation to her husband by helping to increase their family income through her work. To meet her family's needs, she started a business raising sows. Starting with just one sow, she now has two. The sows cost her 800,000 Rupiah a piece, and, tended well, produce 5-10 healthy piglets. The sale of the piglets from both sows can results in revenue of as much as 5,000,000 Rupiah. She has already been in this business for several years, which has paid for her children's primary education and a small amount has helped her to start a small store in front of her house. From all of her hard work she has gained lots of useful experience in growing her business. She now sees a new opportunity to move her business even further forward. She plans to raise fatted pigs, which are in high demand for use in Bali's famous roasted pork dish (babi guling). In fact, restaurants specializing in babi guling are becoming more and more common in Bali. Because of the excellent market for fatted pigs, Ni Nengah Tayu plans to raise additional sows. To help her with the expansion of her business, Ni Nengah Tayu would like to borrow capital to purchase more stock animals and special feed for all of her sows.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Ni Nengah Tayu adalah seorang ibu rumah tangga yang benar-benar memahami bahwa tanggung jawabnya di keluarga tidak hanya mengasuh anak, tetapi juga berkewajiban membantu suami untuk meningkatkan kesejahteraan keluarga. Menjalankan usaha ternak babi khususnya penginduk menjadi pilihannya. Berawal dari seekor penginduk saja saat ini Ni Nengah Tayu sudah mampu memelihara dua ekor penginduk. Penginduk ini dibelinya seharga Rp. 800.000,- per ekor dan dipelihara dengan baik dan bisa menghasilkan 5-10 ekor anak yang sehat sehingga kalau dihitung, hasil penjualannya bisa mencapai Rp. 5.000.000 dari ke dua ekor penginduk tersebut. Usaha yang sudah digeluti selama beberapa tahun ini mampu membiayai kebutuhan pendidikan anaknya dan sebagian kecil disisihkannya untuk membuka warung kecil di depan rumahnya. Dari kegiatan usahanya ini Ni Nengah Tayu mendapat banyak pengalaman yang bermanfaat dalam pengembangan usahanya. Ni Nengah Tayu melihat adanya peluang untuk mengembangkan usahanya supaya lebih maju yaitu dengan banyaknya permintaan ternak babi penggemukan untuk babi guling, karena Bali sangat terkenal dengan masakan babi gulingnya, sehingga usaha rumah makan babi guling juga semakin banyak. Rencananya adalah selain penginduk Ni Nengah Tayu juga memelihara penggemukan karena pemasarannyapun juga sudah jelas. Dalam hal ini DINARI memberikan dukungan dalam bentuk pimjaman modal usaha dan ini dimanfaatkannya untuk pembelian stok pakan yang bisa mencukupi semua kebutuhan pakan ternaknya.

loans.use: for purchasing sows and feed

loans.name: Aah

texts.en: Aah is 40 years old and has a 16 year old child. She runs a small food stall where she sells regular snacks and fried snacks.  She usually earns US $5 per day. She also sells meatballs and earns US $5 per day from this business. Her husband, K., is a driver who earns US $20 per week.  She is requesting a IDR 500,000 loan to buy the supplies she needs to make the food that she sells.  She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy groceries to produce her foods

loans.name: Abdurauf

texts.en: Abdurauf A. lives in Khujand; he is married and has 4 children.  He has been an active and strongly motivated client of MicroInvest since 2004.  His credit history makes him eligible to receive new and larger loans. Mr A. is experienced in the business of making pickled and salted foods (pickled cucumbers and tomatoes, assorted pickled vegetables), jams, and juices. Because he buys wholesale and in bulk, his prices are lower than regular bazaar prices. He offers a wide assortment of goods for clients of different means. He is asking for a loan of $1200 to expand his assortment of goods and to purchase new equipment for preparing different recipes. He would like to increase his income and give his children a good education.

loans.use: To purchase new food-preparation equipment

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita is 20 years old and the mother of one year old child. She has been selling clothing on credit after becoming a member of MBK.  In this business, she can earn US $2 per day. Her husband, B., works at repair shop and earns US $3 per day. She requests a loan to buy more goods to sell. She is willing to repay the loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: to buy more clothing

loans.name: Miyasar

texts.en: Miyasar S. lives in the Gafurov region; she is married and has 4 children.  She has been a successful client of MicroInvest since 2005.  She runs a business selling clothing and shoes for children and also sells fruit in an Afghan bazaar, where she has many loyal clients and much demand.  She requests a loan of $450 to increase her fruit turnover.

loans.use: to increase fruit turnover

loans.name: I Putu Agus Sumerta

texts.id:
As head of his household, I Putu Agus Sumerta is responsible for meeting all of the needs of his family. He currently has two children, Intan and Noval, and his income is what ensures their survival. In 2002, the Bali bombings almost completely destroyed the Balinese economy. One of the hardest-hit industries was tourism. After the bombings, hotels had to lay off many of their employees. Unfortunately, due to the circumstances, I Putu Agus Sumerta was let go from his job at a hotel in Denpasar. Like many others, he had to return to his home village to begin looking for a new source of income. He decided to go into the clothes tailoring business. To learn the trade, he studied with his mother, at the home where he was born, in the village of Candikusuma. With a completely manual sewing machine (they have no electricity), he is now able to make a full outfit worth 40,000 Rupiah in just one 8am to 5pm work day. He has been very successful in his business, gaining more customers every day. For major holidays he has lines of customers waiting to put in orders. In fact, due to the limitations of the tools he is using, he is having to decline more and more customers because he is afraid he won't be able to complete their orders on time. I Putus Agus Sumerta would like to borrow 2,000,000 Rupiah to purchase a Dynamo electric generator that he can attach to his sewing machine to increase his production and therefore better help his family meet their day-to-day needs. His oldest daughter is in her final year of primary school, and he also wants to use his increased income to pay for her continued education.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Sebagai Kepala keluarga yang harus bertanggung jawab dalam memenuhi seluruh kebutuhan keluarganya , I Putu Agus Sumerta yang kini telah di karuniai dua orang anak yakni Intan & Noval sangat memerlukan pekerjaan yang bisa menjamin kelangsungan hidup keluarga. Hal itu sebenarnya sudah pernah terwujud ,sebelum suatu kejadian (Bom Bali )terjadi,yang membuat hampir seluruh perekonomian di bali terpuruk , khususnya dalam bidang perhotelan .Banyak hotel maupun usaha yang berkaitan dengan pariwisata mengalami kebangkrutan yang Berdampak pada pemutusan hubungan kerja. Seperti yang terjadi terhadap Putu Agus Sumerta.Mantan seorang karyawan salah satu hotel di Denpasar ini harus rela balik kekampungnya dan harus memulai mencari sumber pendapatan yang baru . Menjahit pakaian menjadi pilihan Putu Agus ,ketrampilan yang di peroleh dari Ibu kandungnya itu di jalankannya di rumah tempat kelahirannya yaitu di desa Candikusuma . Dengan mesin jahit manual (tanpa tenaga penggerak listrik) dalam sehari Putu Agus bisa menyelesaikan satu stel pakaian dengan ongkos/upah sebesar Rp 40.000,- ini di kerjakan mulai jam 8 pagi sampai jam 5 sore. Hasil jaritan Putu Agus Sangat baik sehingga pelangganyapun bertambah banyak lebih lebih menjelang hari raya banyak pelanggan yang antri untuk di buatkan Baju maupun pakaian lainya . Bahkan tak jarang Putu agus harus menolak pesanan karena takut tak bisa menyelesaikan tepat waktu karena keterbatasan alat yang dimiliki. Putu Agus memerlukan pinjaman modal dari Dinari sebesar Rp 2 .000.000,- untuk membeli Dinamo listrik yang dipasangkan pada mesinjahitnya sebagai tenaga pengerak Agar hasil produksinya meningkat dan pendapatannya juga bertambah Sehingga dapat memenuhi kebutuhan sehari-hari dan juga untuk biaya pendidikan putri sulungnya yang sekarang sudah kelas 5 SD

loans.use: To buy a Dinamo electric generator for a manual sewing machine

loans.name: Ahammd Fawood

texts.en: Ahammd Fawood lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and has one son and lives with his own family. He is a doctor. He completed his education in India. When he came back two years ago, he opened a drug store in Kabul. He wants to expand his business, so he wants to take an individual loan to complete his stock. He wants to make a good income to help his family. He is happy now.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Nyai

texts.en: Nyai N. is 31 years old and a mother of a 13 year old child. She sells kerosene, spices and snacks at her house and earns US $7 per day. Her husband, Bayu, sells chicken at the market and earns US $7.5 per week. She is requesting a IDR 500,000 loan to buy more goods to sell at her stall.  She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her stall

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en: Firuza M. lives in Khujand; she is married and has one child.  She has been an active and serious client of MicroInvest since 2006, and because of her credit history she is now eligible for larger loans. She works in the joint-stock company “Navbakhor” making winter wear.  Firuza M. has a side business in embrodiery. She uses regional motifs and brightly colored thread in her embroidery, which make her needlework unique and eye-catching. Mrs M. is asking for a loan of $450 to purchase special brightly colored embroidery thread.

loans.use: To buy embroidery thread

loans.name: Gulbakhor

texts.en: Gulbakhor M. lives in Khujand; she is married and has 3 children.  Mrs. M. has been a successful, strongly motivated client of MicroInvest since 2006. Her credit history makes her eleigible for larger loans. She works in the joint-stock company "Navbakhor" making winter wear. Gulbakhor M. developed her own patterns and used special accessories to make the clothing more individual. She has the a loyal clientele of long standing. She has a lot of ideas on how to make her work more efficient and how to broaden the product line. She would like to modernize her business and requests a loan of $725 to buy a computerized sewing machine. Her dream is to open her own shop in the future.

loans.use: To buy a computerized sewing machine

loans.name: Nyai

texts.en: Nyai is a 43 year old widow. She has a small food stall from which she sells snacks, fried snacks and coconut milk rice. She can earn US $20 per day. She has had to work hard for a living since her husband passed away. She needs a IDR 900,000 loan to expand her food stall. She is willing to repay the loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: to expand her food stall

loans.name: Lutfy

texts.en: Lutfy J. has worked in a joint-stock company for a long time as a strongly-motivated worker.  She makes  both European-style clothing and traditional national dress.  She has been a dedicated client of MicroInvest since 2006.  Ms. J. requests a loan of $300 to buy special equipment necessary for needlework.

loans.use: to buy special needlework equipment

loans.name: Nurbaeti

texts.en: Nurbaeti is 38 years old and the mother of a 10 year old child. She has been producing and selling cakes for a living and can earn US $3 per day. Her husband, A., is a driver who earns IDR 900,000 per week. Nurbaeti really needs a IDR 500,000 loan to expand her business with the hopes that with the loan she can earn more income for her family. She is willing to repay the loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Subhani

texts.en: I sell milk from my house. I need a loan of $350 to buy an additional cow for my dairy business. My husband works at a factory that pays very low wages. We have five children, and it's hard to manage our household expenses with our current income.  Therefore, I plan to expand my existing business. Having another cow will help us generate greater profits.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Noor

texts.en: I live with my family in a two-room brick house, located in small, semi-urban Raiwind, Pakistan. My husband I live with our eight children--six boys and two girls. My husband is a daily wage laborer. He is a contractor in the construction business. To supplement my husband’s income, I sell milk. A year ago, I took out a loan for my business, which resulted in higher profits. I was able to save $500 over the year for myself. Right now, I'm asking for a loan of $350 to expand my business and buy a cow.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Mutaramkhon

texts.en: Mutaramkhon V. lives in Khujand; she is married and has 3 children.  She works in the joint-stock company “Navbakhor” making women's wear.  Mutaramkhon V. has been an active, serious, and strongly motivated client of MicroInvest since 2005. Her credit history makes eligible for larger loans. She has successfully paid back past loans thanks to a stable business and increased income.  To manufacture women's wear, she needs fabric, accessories, and various other essentials, because she develops her own patterns. She is asking for loan of $600 to purchase new fabric for winter suits. Her dream is to open her own business in which she can realize the ideas she has today.

loans.use: To purchase fabric for winter suits

loans.name: Onih

texts.en: Onih is 20 years old and is the mother of a 1 year old child. She sells sandals on credit and usually earns US $7 per week. Her husband, Y., is a driver who earns US $2 per day.  Therefore, she has to work hard to earn extra income for the family. She needs a IDR 900,000 loan to expand her business and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Zaitooni

texts.en: I am Zaitooni B. from Raiwind, a small town in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of six: two daughters and four sons. My husband is a farmer and I sell milk. At times, I also go into the fields and help my husband there. We grow seasonal crops in our fields. I need to buy an additional cow for our business and therefore require a loan of $350.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Muyasar

texts.en: Muyasar O. lives in the Gafurov region.  She works in the joint-stock company “Navbakhor” making ladies' suits.  She has been an active, serious client of MicroInvest since 2005.  A stable business and increased income have helped her pay back previous loans.  She is a skilled seamstress and works from her own patterns. Ms. O. would like to buy different fabrics to make suits according to the season.  She is asking for a loan of $400 to buy materials for winter suits so that she can offer a wider selection.

loans.use: To purchase fabric for winter suits

loans.name: Majeedan

texts.en: My name is Majeedan B.. I live in a small underdeveloped town, Raiwind, Pakistan. I am married and a mother of seven: three boys and four girls. My husband is a daily wage laborer and I offer midwife services to women in my area. My daughter is an artist and she embroiders clothes. She wants to buy an embroidery machine for her business. I hope she will do well because she is very ambitious and hardworking. Please lend us $225.

loans.use: Buy an embroidery machine

loans.name: Nurhayati

texts.en: Nurhayati is 23 years old and has a 3 year old child. She sells fruit salad called 'rujak' and usually earns US $5 per day. Her husband, Y., is a laborer who earns US $1.5 per day.  Therefore, she must work hard to earn extra income for the family. She is requesting a IDR 500,000 loan to expand her business and is willing to repay the loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Savrinisso

texts.en: Savrinisso J. lives in Khujand; she is married and has 3 children.  She works in the joint-stock company “Navbakhor” and sells suits.  She has been an active, strongly motivated client of MicroInvest since 2006.  In addition to selling suits, she has a sideline dying and painting leather.  She is experienced in this craft. Mrs J. is asking for a loan of $600  to develop this parallel leather business so as to increase the family income and give her children a good education.

loans.use: To develop leather-dying/painting business

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en: I am Parveen A.. I am married and a mother of five: three girls and two boys. I live with my family in Raiwind, a small town in Pakistan. At present, only my eldest daughter attends school while the others are small. I embroider clothes on order from my neighborhood clients. I wish to expand my business and buy an embroidery machine for this purpose. Please lend me $250. I hope to secure a sound economic and promising future for my family.

loans.use: Buy an embroidery machine

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en: I am Parveen A.. I am married and a mother of five: three girls and two boys. I live with my family in Raiwind, a small town in Pakistan. At present, only my eldest daughter attends school while the others are small. I embroider clothes on order from my neighborhood clients. I wish to expand my business and buy an embroidery machine for this purpose. Please lend me $250. I hope to secure a sound economic and promising future for my family.

loans.use: Buy an embroidery machine

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en: Mavluda Y. lives in B. Gafurov. She works in the Joint-Stock company “Navbakhor" in the commercial industry of the ladies' dressmaking. M. Y. is an active client of MicroInvest from 2007, and already she recommended herself as a serious and strong-motivated client. M. Y. works in the dresses development, design and making. This kind of business requires investments from time to time. She intends to purchase the special threads and equipment because she is a very experienced seamstress.

loans.use: To purchase special thread and equipment

loans.name: Neneng

texts.en: Neneng is 32 years old and has a 14 year old child. She sells bedding sheets door-to-door on credit.  She can earn up to IDR 500,000 per month. Her husband, P., is a driver who earns US $2 per day. She requests a IDR 900,000 loan to buy more goods to sell. She is willing to repay the loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: to buy more goods

loans.name: Ghafooran

texts.en: I am 42, married and a mother of six: three boys and three girls. I sew clothes for my neighborhood clients, and my husband is a hakim (a person who cures various diseases through the use of herbs). My son is a milkman and he wants to buy a cow for his business for which we need a loan of $250. I assure you we will repay the loan on time in a responsible manner.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Savrinisso

texts.en: Savrinisso Z. lives in Khujand; she is married and has 5 children. She works in the Joint-Stock Company “Navbakhor” in the commercial industry of hosiery production (jackets, caps, gloves). She has been an active client of MicroInvest from 2005 and the indicators show income increase and business stability. She has the experience of 12 years in needleworking (clothing production). Now she requires the loan for a special equipment purchase because she is very skilled seamstress. As a clothing maker, she requires the special equipment that makes the goods of better quality and style.

loans.use: A special purchase of equipment

loans.name: Amna

texts.en: I am Amna B.. I am a mother of six: four boys and two girls. Currently, only the elder two attend school while the others are too small. My husband works for skimpy pay and I own a few cows and sell their milk. Last year, I took a loan for my business, which resulted in increased profits, and I was able to save $250. Now I wish to further expand my business and require a loan of $350 for this purpose.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Rano

texts.en: Rano K. lives in Khujand; she is married and has 3 children. She works in the Joint-Stock company “Navbakhor" in the commercial industry of the ladies' dresses and fancy clothing. She has been the client of MicroInvest from 2006 and works with MicroInvest because she trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. She is very experienced and her total work experience consists of 22 years. Now R. K. requires the loan for the purchase of winter-weight materials that she would like to use in future dressmaking.

loans.use: To puchase winter-weight materials

loans.name: Sumaira

texts.en: I am 25, married, and a mother of two: one girl and one boy. My son attends kindergarten and my daughter is too small to attend school at the present. I operate a small beauty parlor and also offer tailoring services to women in my neighborhood. The number of clients at my parlor is increasing day by day, and I need to buy a stock of cosmetics to serve them in an efficient manner. Please lend me $175 for this purpose.

loans.use: Expand beauty salon

loans.name: Gulnora

texts.en: Gulnora I. lives in Khujand; she is married and has 2 children. She works in the Joint-Stock company “Navbakhor" in the commercial industry of making ladies' jackets. She has been one of the active clients of MicroInvest from 2005. Her business is stable. She is very experienced in making ladies' jackets. Now she requires the loan to improve the needle (sewing) department's variety and staffing. That gives her additional opportunities for the ladies' jacket-making.

loans.use: To imporve the needle (sewing) department

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en: I am Rubina B. from a small semi-urban Raiwind, around 50 kilometers away from Lahore, second largest city in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of four children: three boys and one girl. My eldest son attends school and is in grade two. The others are not school age yet.  I sew clothes on order from neighborhood clients, and my husband operates a grocery store. He started this store with the loan we took from Asasah, a microfinance institution. Our store does well and therefore we managed to offer PCO services at our store. We need to further expand our business for which we would like a loan of $350. My husband plans to buy stock of various items with this money.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en: Rustam G. lives in Yova; he is married and has 2 children. He is one of the active clients of MicroInvest since 2005. By his professional background he is the teacher, but for the last 10 years he has been a businessman. He works in Panjshanbe Bazaar where his shop is located, and he sells ladies' wear. R. G. has a wide assortment, but he wants to import new fashions demanded among the population today. He requires a loan to widen the existing assortment and to develop his business of ladies' wear selling.

loans.use: To widen the existing assortment and to develop his business of ladies' wear sales

loans.name: Sam Bath

texts.en:
Mr. H. Sam Bath (age 49) and his family live in a small village off of National Road 2, about fifteen kilometers south of Phnom Penh. H. and his wife (age 47) have been married since 1979 and have eight children, one of whom studies in school. The others work in nearby garment factories. His wife has a small stand selling groceries and other household goods in front of their house (see photo). H. has been driving a motorbike taxi in Phnom Penh for ten years. His wife has had her shop for the same amount of time.

He is requesting this, his family’s eighth loan from Maxima, to buy a secondhand motorbike and to buy supplies for his wife’s shop. Phnom Penh may well be one of the world’s largest cities void of even one municipal bus. Motorbike taxis and tuk-tuks are the preferred and, with the rare exception of an automobile taxi, only way to get around. On a good day, H. can make about 15,000 Riel (US $3.75).

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and supplies for a shop.

payments.comment: Pay off the loan early before contract.

loans.name: Muidinkhuja

texts.en: Muidinkhuja S. lives in Khujand. He applied first to MicroInvest in 2007, but he already is the permanent client of MicroInvest because he trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. He has a business in shoes sales. Working in Panjshanbe Bazaar, M. S. meets hard competitors--that is why he wants to widen the existing assortment of winter children's wear. He has the business experience of 5 years of selling. Now he requires a loan to develop and widen the new models of the winter child wear and import new styles.

loans.use: To develop and widen the existing business

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en: I am Shahnaz B. from the small town of Raiwind, Pakistan. I sew clothes for my neighborhood clients, and my husband works at a government institution for small pay, which is insufficient for our family. Therefore, my husband sells milk to increase his income. I am a mother of eight: four girls and four boys.  All of my children attend school except the youngest three who are not school age yet. My husband feels that we should raise our living standard, and hence expand our milk business. Please lend us $175 to buy an additional cow for the business.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Leang

texts.en: Mrs. C. Leang (age 30) and her family live in a small village off of National Road 2, about fifteen kilometers south of Phnom Penh. Leang and her husband (age 37) have been married for 12 years and have four children, three of whom study in school in their village.  The fourth is still too young to attend.  Her husband (not pictured) has been driving a motorbike taxi in Phnom Penh for about ten years.  Prior to that, he was a “cyclo,” or bicycle taxi, driver.  They are requesting this, their fourth loan from Maxima, to buy a secondhand motorbike.  Motorbike taxis are by far the most common form of transportation in Phnom Penh.  Leang’s husband leaves their house at 4:00 A.M. and returns around 6:00 P.M.  In a typical day he makes about 15,000 Riel (US $3.75).

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Akou

texts.fr:
Akou is a married woman with four children who has been running a little grocery store for more than 15 years. The income from her business allows her to pay the school fees for her four children and provide for her family's most basic needs. Akou is requesting this loan so that she can meet her customers' demand for tomatoes for the end of the year (the holiday season).

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Akou O. est une femme mariée avec 04 enfants ; exerce l'activité d'épicerie depuis plus de 15 ans. Le revenu de cette activité lui a permis de scolariser ses 4 enfants et de subvenir au besoin élementaire de la famille. C'est Pour satisfaire la demande en tomate en fin d'année ,que Akou O. soulicitte cet emprunt.

loans.use:
to purchase 20 baskets of tomatoes in Dapaon and re-sell them in Kpalimé

Acheter 20 paniers de tomates à Dapaon pour les revendre à Kpalimé

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Mr. O. Thy (age 50) and his family live in a small village off of National Road 2, about fifteen kilometers south of Phnom Penh. O. and his wife (age 47 -- see photo), have been married since 1980 and have two children. Both children have finished studying in school. One is married with two children of her own. All of them, as well as two grandparents, live at home – for a total of eight persons.

O. (pronounced “ook”) has fished since he was a young boy. His wife explained that he fishes for two to three months of the year in the Tonle Bassac (river), a tributary of the nearby Mekong. The remainder of the year he fishes in a nearby lake using locally made fish traps (again, see photo). They are requesting this, their eighth loan from Maxima, to buy a cow and fish traps. O.’s wife said a trap costs 70,000 Riel (US $17.50). She also said he can catch twenty kilos on a good day making about 50,000 Riel (US $12.50), depending on the types of fish he catches.

loans.use: To purchase one calf and buy fish traps.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Sophos's Group

texts.en:
These two families live in a small village off of National Road 2, about fifteen kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They are requesting this, their first group loan from Maxima, to buy a second cow and to buy a moto-remorque taxi. Mrs. C. Sophos was selected to be a group leader by members requesting a loan from Maxima.

1. Mrs. C. Sophos (age 25) and her husband (age 28) have been married for two years. They have one child. C. has worked in a nearby garment factory for six years. Her husband drives a moto-remorque taxi. They also raise cows (see image on right of photo). She is requesting a loan from Maxima of US$400. She will use this loan to purchase a cow to raise.

2. Mrs. N. Chanthorn (age 26) and her husband (age 33) have been married since 1997. They have three children, two of whom study in primary school in their village. N. has been working in a garment factory for a year. Her husband also drives a moto-remorque taxi (see image on left of photo -- her husband and son are pictured on one as an illustration.) Closer to Phnom Penh, National Road Two is lined with garment factories. At each shift change, thousands of workers, mostly women, need to be ferried to and from the surrounding villages. Cambodians use the moto-remorque, a very economical combination of a trailer pulled by a 100 or 125cc motorbike. They typically hold as many as eighteen or more people. N. is requesting a loan from Maxima of US$200. She will use this loan to purchase a moto-remorque carriage to provide transportation.

loans.use: Group loan to purchase a cow and a moto-remorque taxi.

loans.name: Lutfy

texts.en: Lutfy M. lives in Khujand; she is married and has 3 children. She is a very active client of MicroInvest since 2005. She has a business selling men's clothing and underwear selling. L. M. works in Panjshanbe Bazaar where her shop is located. She has a wide assortment and follows the new trends and fashions. Now she asks for a loan to import new styles and to widen and the existing assortment.

loans.use: To widen the variety of clothing she sells

loans.name: Sory

texts.en:
Mr. S. Sory (age 61) got married in 1982 and has five children, three sons and two daughters. He has been in the business of raising pigs and growing rice since 1982. His wife, Mrs. Pov Kimsry (age 50) works in growing rice and raising pigs with him too. Two of their children are studying and the other three of them are working. Neither husband and wife have finished primary school.

He has borrowed money from MAXIMA twice before. He is now requesting a loan of $1,000. He will use this money to expand the pig raising and rice growing businesses.

loans.use: To expand pig raising  and rice growing businesses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Shaheen

texts.en: I am a mother of four, one who is in school and the others are not. I used to run my own sewing business in a rural area where I live in Pakistan. Now I am planning on taking my tenth grade exams in order to finish school, which I quit a long time ago. Naturally my husband will need to bring in more income to compensate for my work. He runs a food stall and wants to have it repaired and stock up on materials. Hence, we need $175 for this venture which will help attract more customers.

loans.use: Buy stock of various items for the food stall

loans.name: Pat Sok's Group

texts.en:
These two families live in a small village off of National Road Two, about fifteen kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They are requesting this, their first group loan from Maxima, to expand their businesses of producing knives and selling fish. Mr. P. S. was selected to be a group leader by members looking for a loan from Maxima.

1. Mr. P. S. (age 57) got married in 1960 and has four children, two sons and two daughters. He has been in the business of producing knives since 1965. His wife, Mrs. Morm My, is a housewife. Two of their children are married and live in separate houses. The other two of them are working in a garment factory. He is requesting a $200 loan from Maxima to expand his business of producing knives.

2. Mrs. S. Sreymom (age 32) got married in 2002 and has three children, one son and two daughters. She has been in the business of selling fish in her village since 2000. Her husband produces rice wine at home. One of her children is studying in the local school and the other two stay at home. She is requesting a $200 loan from Maxima for her fish sales.

loans.use: Group loan to produce knives and sell fish.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Tasneem

texts.en: I am a mother of two and live in a small town with my children and husband. I need a loan of $350 to buy cloth in bulk, which will help save costs. I purchase cloth from a near-by city, Multan, which is famous for its special Khadi cloth, and then I have local women embroider decorative flowers and paisleys on it. I am quite experienced and have been doing this for the past 10 years and know I will be successful. Last year too, I took a loan to invest in my business and re-invested the profits back into the enterprise, which helped it to grow. While my daughter is married, this time I hope that I will be able to send my son to school with the profits.

loans.use: Buy cloth in bulk

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Mr. K. Soeun, 69, has been married for 49 years. Soeun is a bicycle repairman at his small shop in front of the family home. It's a business he knows well and has been doing for many years. He and his wife have six children, three of whom still live at home and work to help support the family. One of Soeun's daughters, Chanthy, is married with two children. She and her family recently moved back in with Soeun after her mother-in-law died. Now, Chanthy is hoping to relocate her existing restaurant to her parents' home.

Soeun is requesting his seventh loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $500. A portion of the loan will be used to purchase additional parts and inner tubes for repairing bicycles. The bulk of the loan will be used to purchase groceries -- produce, Chinese noodles, meat, sauces -- for his daughter's restaurant. Chanthy already owns all the equipment, furniture and accessories to get the business running again. Now all she needs is the up-front capital to make it happen. Their location is near the ferry stop on their island (just outside of Phnom Penh), and with the long-standing repair shop, it seems guaranteed to attract customers.

loans.use: Buy groceries to open restaurant and parts for bicycles.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Please Delete's Group

texts.en:
DIA, age 54, runs a small breakfast cafe from the porch of their home, which she calls “Mama Kingwiti.” She began this business in 1971. She serves food from 6am-10am daily, charging an average of 45-55 cents per plate. Every day, Dia makes about $5.50-6.50 from her breakfast business. She has been using the profits to make repairs on their home. A long term goal of hers is to one day get electricity in their home.

While Dia and her husband live alone, they have 7 grown children. Some of their children still help Dia cook and serve at her café. Her husband is a retired City Council Member.

Dia is the leader of Subgroup C of group Tuwezeshane (meaning “let's help each other" in Swahili), which totals 24 members. Dia will be sharing this loan with her subgroup members: Kidawa S. (food vendor), Kasim R. (tailor), Asha K. (selling clothes), and Salma M. (selling charcoal). Her subgroup has shared 3 previous loans together, which they paid back successfully.

Dia used the previous loans to increase her food supply for her café. She hopes to use the new loan to do the same in order to continue their house repairs.

In the picture, Dia is on the far right.

loans.use: To expand businesses

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Mr. S. Thy, 28, has been married for 7 years. He and his wife, Dit Sim, have two young children and another one on the way. Like their parents, Thy and Sim are farmers. It's the only work they've ever known. They farm three 30M x 200M plots of land - one that they own and the others that are farmed for produce trade with the owner. It is now the planting season for tomato, cucumber and ginger, and they are busy trying to get all their transplants into the ground. Soon they will plant watermelon and corn too.

Thy is requesting his first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $200. This loan will be used to buy a refurbished water pump for irrigating their fields. The old pump is no longer working and is a necessary piece of equipment. Thy is requesting this loan as they have just had to spend much in up-front costs preparing their fields. They will now not earn any income for another two or three months until they can begin picking the first of the vegetables. As they already have a buyer that purchases their produce, we feel that they have the ability to repay this loan.

loans.use: Buy water pump.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Tojy

texts.en: Tojy B. lives in B.Gafurov; she is married and has a child. She has been an active client of MicroInvest from 2003. Her business is stable. She trades in Panjshanbe Bazaar where her shop is located. She has a good assortment and she is working in the bedding material (cloth) and bedding selling. She has experience in business for 22 years. But working in Panjshanbe Bazaar, T.B. meets hard competitors--that is why she wants to widen the existing assortment of the bedding by importing new varieties.

loans.use: Purchase of new bedding materials and bedding to sell

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mrs. U. Pov, 44, and her husband, Bey Pich, live in a modest wood stilt home. They have five children who still live at home, in addition to two young orphaned relatives. Pov has been a weaver since she was 14 years old. It's a skill she learned from her mother. Now, she is teaching her own daughter, 19, to weave as well. They own two looms. Pich is a moto-taxi driver and operates between their Mekong island of Koh Dach and Phnom Penh.

Pov is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $300. They will use this loan to purchase materials for home repairs. The existing corrugated roof is in bad shape and much of it needs replacement. Pov says the new roof will cost $500, but that they have saved $200 already. As Pov has successfully repaid previous loans, we feel sure she will repay this new loan as well.

loans.use: Buy materials for home repair.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Hana

texts.en: Hana is 44 years old. She lives in south Lebanon in the Nabatieh region. She has a grocery store and needs $300 to buy enough merchandise for the shop. Hana comes from a poor background and is striving to stay independent and to provide for herself.

loans.use: Hana would like to buy enough merchandise for the grocery store.

loans.name: Saven

texts.en:
Mrs. A. Saven, 58, and her husband, Nov Pouk, have a large family. Of 13 children, only seven are still living. These are now grown and married with children of their own. Saven was a weaver when she was younger and taught two of her daughters the skill. One of these daughters, Sivon, still lives with them now, with her husband and young son. Besides weaving, Sivon also raises pigs and sells fish and bananas A. the morning market on the island. Though Pouk is now 60, he still helps to support the family doing construction work, farming and raising cows.

Saven is requesting her fourth loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $350. They will use this loan to purchase food for their pigs. Saven and Sivon are now raising 12 pigs which will be fattened to sell in five months. In the meantime, they must purchase expensive store-bought food for them. They have been running this business for the past eight years and have a buyer thA. will come to their home. Recently, some of their pigs died A. a loss of over $50 each. They hope thA. they will be able to fatten the remainder of the pigs well and make up for their loss.

loans.use: Buy food for pigs.

loans.name: Sahar

texts.en: Sahar is a 30 year old woman who lives with her husband and two children in south Lebanon in the Nabatieh region. Sahar is helping her husband, who is the army, support the family. Sahar processes food that she sells afterwards: vinegar, pickles, etc. She needs a loan of $300 to supply herself with the needed provisions for her business.

loans.use: Sahar would like to supply her processed food business with the needed provisions.

loans.name: Noeun

texts.en:
Mr. N. Noeun, 46, and his wife, Bou Pov, live along National Road 5, about twenty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1985. They have eight children who still live under their custody. Noeun has been a construction worker since 1990 and his family also grows rice. Besides growing rice, Noeun’s wife picks water hyacinths to sell. She dries them in the sun before selling them. One of his sons is working and other four children are studying in primary school.

Noeun is requesting his first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $200. He will use this loan to purchase fertilizer for growing rice.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for growing rice.

loans.name: Wassila

texts.en: Wassila is 35 years old. She lives and works in the region of Nabatieh, in the south of Lebanon. Wassila can be described as a hard worker since she sells pesticides and has also opened a small bakery. She needs a loan of $300 to buy the required merchandise for both her businesses.

loans.use: Wassila would like to buy the required merchandise for her bakery.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mr. M. Mao, 37, and his wife, Kim Chankresna, live along National Road 5, about twenty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1989 and have seven children who still live under their custody. Mao has been a fisherM. since 1990. It's a skill he learned from his parents. He fishes in the river around his village and sells the fish. His wife stays at home and takes care of their children. One of his daughters is working in a garment factory, four of them are studying, and two are still young and stay at home.

Mao is requesting his third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $200. He will use this loan to purchase fishing nets to expand his fishing. As Mao has successfully repaid previous loans, we feel sure he will repay this new loan as well.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Noha

texts.en: Noha is a 46 year old mother of four. She lives in south Lebanon in the Nabatieh region. Noha sells cosmetics but also knits children's clothing. Noha needs a loan of $300 to pay her suppliers in cosmetics so as to benefit from the promotions they are offering.
