loans.use: Noha would like to buy merchandise and benefit from the promotional offers.

loans.name: Sou

texts.en: Mrs. Sou S. V., age 28, works on her plot of land growing vegetables and raising domestic animals. Her husband would like to operate a motor-taxi business to increase the family’s income. They support one child who is too young to attend school and her elderly father who also lives with them. She would like to request a loan of $800 in order to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a taxi business. They anticipate this will earn the family an additional $5 per day in revenue, which will help raise their standard of living and pay for their child’s education.

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike for her husband to operate a taxi business.

loans.name: Mat

texts.en:
Mr. L. Mat, 50, and his wife, Sa Aim Misas, live along National Road 6, about thirty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1983 and have three daughters who still live under their custody. Mat has been a fisherman since his youth. It's a skill he learned from his parents. He fishes in the Mekong River around his village and sells the fish every day. His wife and one of his daughters assist him with the fishing. The other two of his daughters are studying in the local school.

Mat is requesting his first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $400. He will use this loan to purchase fishing nets for $100 and the other $300 will be used to buy a boat motor to get another boat for his fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and a boat motor.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Tres

texts.en:
Mr. L. Tres is 23 years old. He is single and lives with his widowed mother along National Road 6, about thirty kilometers from Phnom Penh. Tres has been a fisherman since 1998.  It's a skill he learned from his brother. He fishes in the Mekong River around his village and sells the fish every day. Beside fishing, Tres also buys and resells recycled material in his village. His mother also helps him with the fishing too. He has not even finished primary school.

Tres is requesting his first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $350.  He will use this loan to purchase fishing nets for his fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets.

payments.comment:
Dear lender,

Mr. Tres Lei paid off his loan early before confract.

Thank you.

loans.name: Krouch

texts.en: Mrs. Krouch R., age 36, is employed at a private company, making around $2 each day. Her husband is also employed at a private company earning about $4 per day. They have four children, one who works with his mother earning about $60 per month and three who are unemployed. She would like to request a loan of $700 in order to improve her house that is now unstable and leaks. She is pictured on the right with her daughter on the left.

loans.use: To improve her house that is now unstable and leaks.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Mrs. Pich S., aged 39, works selling grocery products to the people in her area, earning around $5 each day. Her husband is employed at a private company. They have four children who are students. She would like to request a loan of $700 in order to expand her inventory by adding more grocery items to fulfill her clients’ demands. Her husband is pictured in the photo as she was not available at the time.

loans.use: To expand the inventory of her grocery store.

loans.name: Seab

texts.en:
Mrs. V. Seab, 36, and her husband, Lon Charoeun, have been married since 1989.  They have five children, three sons and two daughters. Seab has been a fish seller since 2002. Her husband is a fisherman. He fishes in the Mekong River for Seab, who sells around the village using her motorbike. Her oldest daughter is weaving silk at home; two of her children are studying in the local school; and the other two are still young and stay at home.   

Seab is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $250.  She will use this loan to purchase silk materials for her daughter’s weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving

loans.name: Hisham

texts.en: Hisham is a 28 year old man. He lives in south Lebanon, in the Nabatieh region. Hisham comes from a poor background. He has a small dental laboratory which is his main source of income. Hisham needs a loan of $1000 to buy the necessary material for his business and for its maintenance.

loans.use: Hisham would like to buy the necessary material for his dental business.

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en: Rashid is a 23 year old man. He lives is south Lebanon in the Nabatieh region. Rashid comes from a poor background but made it on his own and was able to open a barber shop. He needs a loan of $500 to buy the required products to sustain and develop his business.

loans.use: Rashid would like to buy the required products to run his barber shop.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Sok, 41, and her husband, Sor Chanthorn, have been married since 1993. They have four children, two sons and two daughters. Sok has been selling Khmer traditional medicine since 2002. Her husband is a Khmer traditional medicine maker. He learned his skill from his master at Kou Len Mountain in Seam Reap Province. All of their children are studying in the local school.

Sok is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $400. She will use this loan to purchase a motorbike for use in her business selling Khmer traditional medicine.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for selling Khmer traditional medicine.

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Sophea has been married for 12 years. She and her husband have two sons who are studying in the local school.

Sophea is in the business of selling Chinese noodles and coffee at the shop in front of the family home. It's a business she and her husband know well and have been doing for many years. She has one television for her customers to watch boxing in her restaurant. Many people come to her restaurant to eat and drink coffee while they are watching boxing, but Cambodian boxing is shown only one time a week. It is not enough for her customers, so she needs to buy a radar (satellite) to connect to her TV to meet the needs of her customers. Her village has no cable TV.

Sophea is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $1,000. She will use this loan to purchase a radar (satellite) for her restaurant to connect to the boxing channels.

loans.use: To buy a radar (satellite) for her restaurant to connect to the boxing channels.

loans.name: Sat

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Sat, 30, and her husband, Uch Ath, have been married since 1999. They have two children who are studying in the local school. Sat has been a weaver since she was 19 years old. It's a skill she learned from her neighbor. Her husband is a construction worker and does farming. He is growing rice and planting mushrooms. Both husband and wife have not finished secondary school.

Sat is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $600. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials for weaving and buying rice seed for her husband to grow rice.

loans.use: Buying silk materials for weaving and rice seed

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Sout

texts.en: Mrs. Sout S. E., age 25, is a traditional musician, earning around $5 each day. Her husband works driving a trailer attached to a motor-bike to transport passengers, making about $4 per day. They have one child who is too young to attend school. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order seek an additional income source by purchasing pigs to breed and sell. She also plans to fix her husband’s broken trailer so he can better operate his business.

loans.use: To purchase pigs to breed and sell for additional income.

loans.name: Yinnan

texts.en:
Mrs. H. Yinnan, 23, and her husband have been married since 2002. They have no children. Yinnan has been a weaver since she was 18 years old. It's a skill she learned from her neighbor. Her husband is also weaving silk. She is teaching her two younger sisters who are living in the same house with her to weave silk, too. All together, they have four looms for weaving silk.

Yinnan is requesting her second loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $1,000. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials for weaving and set up new looms for her sisters who are now good weavers.

loans.use: Buying silk material and looms for weaving

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Chanthorn

texts.en:
Mrs. P. Chanthorn, 25, and her husband were married in 2006. They have no children. Chanthorn has been a weaver since she was 12 years old. It's a skill she learned from her mother. Her husband is a construction worker. Both husband and wife have not finished secondary school.

Chanthorn is requesting her second loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $500. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials for weaving. As Chanthorn has successfully repaid previous loans, we feel sure she will repay this new loan as well.

loans.use: Buying silk material for weaving

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Joumana

texts.en: Joumana is a 29 year old woman. She lives in south Lebanon, in the region of Nabatieh. Joumana produces processed food and sells plastic containers for kitchen use. Joumana is single and needs to provide for herself. She therefore also works in an industriA. plant that makes jams. She needs $200 to buy the necessary provisions to sustain her own business in producing processed food.

loans.use: Joumana would like to buy provisions for her business.

loans.name: Moufida

texts.en: Moufida is a 58 year old woman who lives in south Lebanon, in the Nabatieh region. Moufida produces processed food and works in an industrial plant that makes jams. She needs $200 to buy the necessary provisions to sustain her own business in producing processed food.

loans.use: Moufida would like to buy the necessary provisions for her business.

loans.name: Subgroup A Of Group Tuwezeshane

texts.en:
GLADIS, age 32, sells powdered soap and new dresses and shoes from door to door to homes, schools, and offices. She works from 10am to 6pm, with a lunch break which she uses to spend time with her children. She began this business in 2001 and now makes about $9 a week from powdered soap sales and $18 from clothing sales.

Before this business, Gladis was a stay-at-home mother. She started working because her husband’s military income wasn’t enough to cover their family’s expenses. Gladis’s business has helped their 3 children (ages 7, 8, and 12) attend school. It has also allowed them to begin building a new house, which they are still in the process of doing.

Gladis is the leader of Subgroup A of group Tuwezeshane (meaning “let’s help each other” in Swahili), which totals 24 members. Gladis will be sharing this loan with her subgroup members: Asha S. (selling clothes), Catherine M. (shop owner), Rose M. (selling groceries), Zuhura K. (selling vegetables), Zuwena C. (selling clothes), and Alex M. (selling clothes). While a few of the members are new, most of this subgroup has shared a previous loan together, which they paid back successfully.

Gladis used the previous loan to buy more stock of powdered soap and new clothes. She hopes to use the new loan for the same purpose.

loans.use: To buy stock of powdered soap and clothing

loans.name: Umrinisso

texts.en:
Umrinisso M. lives in Khujand, is married, and has 5 children. She has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2005. She borrows from MicroInvest because she trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure.

Umrinisso has a business selling cigarettes and packets alongside roasted sunflower seeds. Currently, she earns practically all of her family's income by herself so it is difficult to bring up 5 children. As any mother, she dreams of a good and happy future for her children and that is why she is ready to work every day.

Despite having a lot of ideas, Umrinisso has not had the opportunity to realize them. That is why she now requires a loan of 1600 TJS to purchase additional agricultural and demand goods such as potatoes, onions, carrots, etc. that will allow her to improve the family income and support her business.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural and demand goods for winter

loans.name: Parviz Group

texts.ru:
Group "Parvis" has been successfully obtaining loans for the past few years. All members of the group sell clothes on city markets. Malvuda T. sells clothes that she makes herself. Azizova M. and Hosiyat S. sell children's clothing. They travel to purchase goods themselves every 2 weeks. Sometimes Hosiyat's son helps her. Marifat used to sell clothes on markets, but now she works as a sales woman in a department store.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Группа "Парвиз" кредитуется уже на протяжении нескольких лет. Все участники группы торгуют одеждой на рынках города. Тохирова торгует одеждой которая сама шьет. Муяссар и Хосият торгуют детской одеждой, в месяц 2 раза они сами ездят за товаром. Иногда Хосият помогает сын. Марифат раньше торговала на рынке, на данный момент она торгует в магазине детской одеждой.

loans.use: Clothing Sales

loans.name: Mutaramkhon

texts.en: Mutaramkhon V. lives in Khujand; she is married and has 3 children. She works in the Joint-Stock Company “Navbakhor” in the commercial industry of making lady’s mantles (clothing, cloaks or robes). She has been the client of MicroInvest from 2005. She applies straight to MicroInvest because she trusts the loan procedure implemented by MicroInvest--as business stability increases, a person may request bigger loans. Working in clothing making, she requires special furnishings and materials (material for the seasonal suit-making). These make the produced goods better quality and more attractive. She is having a lot of interesting ideas now for clothing, so Mutaramkhon V. requests a loan for the winter material purchase for making winter suits.

loans.use: Purchase of materials appropriate for winter

loans.name: Zamira

texts.en: Zamira is very creative. Her goal of participating in the Kiva program is to purchase different kinds of New Year's clothes for her little clients. She wants to make holidays more interesting and unforgettable for children, and she wans to supply her market with more holiday dresses. During her shop's activity (5 years), she noticed that children from her region (J.Rasulov)have not had the opportunity to buy New Year clothes. She had seen other children from foreign countries meet the New Year wonderfully, and she wants children from her region to meet the New Year holiday also with great pleasure. That is why she ordered to her friend who brings goods from Bishkek to export New Year costumes for her. She needs a loan to pay for this batch of goods.

loans.use: Purchase of clothes for the New Year (a special holiday) for her little clients.

loans.name: Mutriba

texts.en: Mutriba G. lives in Khujand; she is married and has 2 children. She has been a client of MicroInvest in 2007 but already has recommended herself as serious and executive client. She trades in the Panjshanbe Bazaar where her shop for  bedding sales is located. She has a good assortment and she is working. Now she requires a loan for the winter materials purchase that will allow her to improve her business condition.

loans.use: Purchase of materials and bedding for winter months' sales

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en: I live in Vehari, a small town in Pakistan, with my husband and eight children in a three room house. I need $175 for my embroidery business to buy some cloth and threads. I sew and embroider clothes and sell them in Vehari locally. Sometimes I commission other women in my neighbourhood to embroider these clothes if I have too much business, and in this way help out my community. I am sure I can return your loan.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Eldorjon

texts.en: Eldorjon is the father of three children. He lives in J.Rasulov and his trade place is located in the food market in his region. He buys his flour from Khujand by lots and sells them retail at his place. He has stabile profit and his business is developing every month. Also his wife is his business partner and sells flour with him. Presently flour is expensive in Khujand, Tadjikistan, and he needs extra capital for making the purchase of the next batch. In the future he plans to involve his son in this business and rent one more place for him.

loans.use: Purchase the next batch of flour to sell.

loans.name: Matluba

texts.en: Matluba N. lives in Khujand; she is married. She works in the Joint-Stock Company, Navbakhor, in the commercial industry of the national lady’s dresses and fancy works. She has been the client of MicroInvest since 2006, and she works with MicroInvest because she trusts their loan procedure. Now Matluba N. requires a loan for the computer-machine purchase that will make the work more effective and increase the quality of the goods.

loans.use: A computer-driven machine.

loans.name: Radwan

texts.en: Radwan is a 27 year old man who lives in south Lebanon in the region of Saida. Radwan owns a mechanic workshop in which he fixes cars and sells auto parts. Radwan works with his father in the car sector. He needs a loan of $1200 to help him buy a car for his business. This is the third time Radwan is asking for a loan from A. Majmoua. He has a solid history with the association.

loans.use: Radwan would like to buy a car for his business.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Mrs. Patience A. is 40 years old and is married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells tailoring materials.This business was started in 1999. She is requesting a loan of $450 to buy a sewing machine and more  tailoring material for sales.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and more tailoring materials for sale.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is 23 years old. He lives in the south of Lebanon, in the Saida region. Mohamad owns a grocery shop from which he provides for his family, his wife and child. In order to have two income sources, Mohamad also sells coal. He needs $1000 to buy merchandise for his grocery store.

loans.use: Mohamad would like to buy merchandise for his grocery store.

loans.name: Yassine

texts.en: Yassine is a 25 year old man who lives in south Lebanon, in the region of Saida. Yassine is a barber and needs $1000 to buy the required products for his business. This is the second time Yassine is asking for a loan from A. Majmoua. He is an honest and hardworking micro-entrepreneur.

loans.use: Yassine would like to buy the required products for his barber shop.

loans.name: Anorjon

texts.en: Anorjon is an experienced businesswoman as she has had her business of selling curtains for over 5 years. Her husband and son are her business partners. Her husband is responsible for making purchases from Dubai, Saudi Arabia. She, with her son, sells curtains at her business place in J. Rasulov market, Tadjikistan. Her business is going well and she has many constant clients who make orders according to their individual styles. She has attracted many clients by the variety of her curtains. Now she is requesting extra capital for making the next purchase of modern curtains.

loans.use: Purchase of 10 rolls of curtains of different sizes, from 1.5 to 3 metres wide.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Mrs. Florence A. sells bags of rice, salt, oil and tin tomatoes. She is 41years old, and is married with 2 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has five years of experience in her business. She is requesting the loan to buy more bags of rice, oil and tin tomatoes for sale.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, tin tomatoes & oil to sell.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 54 year old man who lives with his family in south Lebanon, in the region of Saida. Mohamad owns a store in which he sells vegetables and groceries. This is the 4th time Mohamad is asking for a loan from A. Majmoua. This time he needs $1200 to buy the necessary merchandise for the sustainability and development of his business.

loans.use: Mohamad would like to buy more groceries and merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Bahri

texts.ru:
Bahri is a nurse in an emergency facility of a hospital. She is 56 years old. She lives with her mother and her grandson. She would really like to give her youngest son a wedding present. Her oldest son lives in Russia and can not send her money often. Bahri's salary is too small to make a large purchase by herself. This is why she turned to Microinvest for credit.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Шарифова работает медсестрой в Скорой помощи ей 56 лет. Она живет с матерью и внуком. Она решила сделать младшему сыну свадебный подарок, поэтому поводу обратилась в Микроинвест и посчитала это удобным. Так как старший ее сын находится в Росии, деньги отправляет очень редко. Ее месячная заработная плата не позволяет сделать крупные покупки.

loans.use: Consumer credit

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 57 year old man who lives with his family in south Lebanon, in the region of Saida. Mohamad owns a grocery store. His wife helps him in the shop. Mohamad is also a tiler who manages construction workshops. This is the 6th time Mohamad is asking for a loan from A. Majmoua. This time he needs $1200 to buy the necessary merchandise for the sustainability and development of his grocery store.

loans.use: Mohamad would like to buy the necessary merchandise for his grocery store.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Mrs. Elizabeth E. is 32 years old, and is married with 4 children. She lives in Ehakpen, Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells tin tomatoes and drinks. She has been in business for 2 years now. She is seeking the loan to buy drinks for sale and more tin tomatoes.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and tin tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Onaudhe

texts.en: Onaudhe L. is 27 years old and lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. He sells clothes in the market. He has 7 years of experience in this business and he is a LAPO member. He needs the loan to enable him to buy more clothes to sell. He thanks you

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Kevin

texts.fr:
Mr. Kevin A., 30, is married and the father of two children. He owns a little shop that sells shoes, and he has been in this business for 5 years. His earnings allow him to support his family and to pay the school fees for his two children. The requested loan will allow him to enlarge his store so that he can better satisfy the needs of his customers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Agé de 30 ans, marié et père de 2 enfants; Mr Kevin A. est propriétaire d'une boutique de vente de chaussures. Il exercice cette activité depuis cinq ans . Les produits de son activité lui permettent de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille et de payer l'écolage de ses enfants . Le présent emprunt lui permettra d'agrandir son magazin afin de satisfaire les besoins de la clientèle

loans.use:
to buy 10 cases of shoes to re-sell on the local market

acheter 10 caisses de chaussures pour les revendre sur le marché local

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Majida

texts.en: Majida lives in the region of Aley. She has five children and is working to provide her with family a decent living. Majida does crochet work and all kinds of handicrafts. She needs a loan of $300 in order to buy the needed material for her crochet and handicraft work.

loans.use: Majida would like to buy the needed material for her crochet and handicraft work.

loans.name: Rania

texts.en: Rania lives in the region of Aley. She has two children and is working to support her family. Rania does all kinds of handicrafts especially. She needs a loan of $300 in order to buy the needed material for her handicraft work. Rania is determined to sustain and develop her business.

loans.use: Rania would like to buy the needed material for her handicraft work.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mrs. Mary A. is 40 yrs old, is married and has five children. She is a designer who sews clothes for sale. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for 10 years. She is requesting a loan to enable her buy more materials to make clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more materials for making Clothes for sale.

loans.name: Wissam

texts.en: Wissam lives in the region of Aley. She has two children and is working to provide her family with a decent living. Wissam does crochet work and handicrafts. She needs a loan of $300 in order to buy the needed material for her crochet and handicraft work.

loans.use: Wissam would like to buy the needed material for her crochet and handicraft work.

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr:
Mr. Kossi A. is 35, married, and the father of two children. He has a carpentry workshop with machines that plane lumber. To meet the needs of his clientele, Mr. A. would like to open a sales point for planks in his workshop. This business will generate supplementary income which will allow Mr. A. to hire two additional employees. His increased income will also permit him to better meet his family's needs.

Mr. A. is a dynamic person and is well versed in this business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Monsieur Kossi est agé de 35 ans , marié et père deux 2 enfants. Il a un atelier de menuiserie avec des machines qui rabotent . Pour satisfaire sa clientèle Monsieur Kossi A. désire mettre en place un dépôt de vente de planche dans son atelier. Cette activité va engendrer les revenus supplémentaires qui permettront à A. de recruter deux employers supplémentaires. Son revenu va augmenter sensiblement pour faire face aux charges familliales.

Monsieur A. est dynamique et connaît parfaitement le secteur.

loans.use:
to buy 450 planks at Badou that he will retail in the local market of Kpalimé

acheter 450 planches à Badou pour les revendre en détail sur le marché local de Kpalimé

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Raghida

texts.en: Raghida lives in the region of Aley in Lebanon. She has three children and is working to support her family. Raghida sells plastic containers used for food preservation. She needs a loan of $700 in order to buy the needed merchandise for her business. Raghida is determined to sustain and develop her business.

loans.use: to buy the needed merchandise for her business

loans.name: Joumana

texts.en: Joumana lives in the region of Aley in Lebanon. She has three children and is working to support her family. Joumana sells plastic containers used for food preservation. She needs a loan of $800 to buy the needed merchandise for her business. Joumana is determined to sustain and develop her business.

loans.use: To buy the needed merchandise for her business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Mrs. Roes E. is 46yrs old and is married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, E. State, Nigeria. She sells fairly used clothes and has been in business since 2004. She requests a loan of $200 to buy more fairly used clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more fairly used clothes to sell

loans.name: Milka

texts.en: Milka is a 40-year old married mother of five living children. She lives with her husband who is also a small-scale businessman in Nyamasaria in Kisumu, Kenya. She operates her cereal business along the Kisumu-Nairobi highway. She started her business in 2000. She normally buys and sells dry maize (corn) to her customers. Over the years, she has been able to generate enough income, especially during the dry season when selling prices are high. Her hard work, perseverance, good reputation, and seven years in business along with a well-established client base ensure that her business will continue to grow. She has applied for a loan of US $600, which she plans to use to purchase an additional stock of cereals in bulk.

loans.use: Purchase additional stock of cereals.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Kisumu Medical & Education Trust (K-MET) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Mrs. Esther O. is 46 years old, married and has 6 children. She hails from Benin City. She sells fairly used clothes. She needs a loan to buy more fairly used clothes to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more fairly used clothing to sell

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Mrs. Christiana O. sells yams in the market. She is 46 years old and married with 7 children. She hails from Ohenhen in Benin City, Edo State Nigeria. She has been in business since 1999. She needs a loan to enable her to buy more yams to sell.

loans.use: To buy more yams to sell

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam K. is a dynamic 34-year-old woman. She is married and has three children. Mariam is a farmer and owns a piece of land that her parents gave to her. She cultivates several vegetables, such as tomatoes, cucumbers, carrots and eggplants. Mariam sells her products wholesale in the markets of Sassandra, a rural city on the southwest Atlantic coast of Cote d'Ivoire. Mariam belongs to some women's trade cooperatives. She would like to acquire new equipment, such as watering cans, shovels and wheelbarrows.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural equipment

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas B. sells drinks and requests a loan of $300 to buy more drinks to sell. She is 42 years, married and has 8 children .She hails from Benin City. She has been in this business since 2005. She promises to pay back within 8 months

loans.use: To buy more drinks for sale

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan O. is 27 years old and is married with 3 children. She lives in Benin City . She sells firewood and local food prepared from cassava (Fufu). She opened her business in 2005. She is in need of a loan to enable her to buy more cassava to prepare Fufu for sale along with firewood.

loans.use: To buy more cassava for Fufu and firewood to sell

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam D. processes and sells various pastes, such as peanut paste, groundnut paste and tomato paste. She is 31 years old and has two children with her partner, who is a farmer in the cocoa production sector. She lives with her family in Sassandra, 120 miles from Abidjan on the southwest Atlantic coast of Cote d'Ivoire. She purchases her raw material from farmers in Sassandra and resells her products in the Sassandra market. Mariam D.'s revenues contribute significantly to the household and the education expenses of her family. She will use the loan to purchase raw material to process her products.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Mariana

texts.es:
Mariana C. lives in Anticrético in the Tembladerani zone of La Paz with her two children. She works as a distributor of food and dietetic products. Mariana has problems at home given that, during construction, the kitchen and bath areas presented filtration problems that are proving inconvenient both for her family as well as their neighbors. The loan she is seeking would be to repair the affected areas of the house. This is her first request for credit, and the financial analysis completed indicates that she would qualify for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Mariana C. vive en Anticrético en la zona de Tembladerani ladera oeste de la Ciudad de La Paz con sus dos hijos; la señora Mariana trabaja como distribuidora de productos alimenticios y dieteticos. La señora Mariana tiene problemas en su domicilio, ya que con el tiempo de edificación, las áreas de la cocina y el baño presentan filtraciones que están provocando inconvenientes tanto para su familia como para sus vecinos. El crédito solicitado será destinado a la refacción de la instalación sanitaria y la refacción de las áreas afectadas en su domicilio. Esta es la primera ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado la califican favorablemente y puede acceder a un crédito.

loans.use: Make repairs to kitchen and bath areas of her house.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Fausto

texts.es:
Señor Fausto G. lives in his own home in the neighborhood of Alto Llojeta on the western side of the City of La Paz with his wife and three children. He works for a woodworker in the neighborhood. With a previous loan, he purchased land with a permit to build a home on it. He is asking for a loan now to use for the construction of a house which will provide his older children with a more comfortable place, primarily for the development of their studies. This is the second time Senor G. has asked for a loan, and the socioeconomic analysis that was completed is favorable and suggests that he can afford the loan. His previous loan has been paid in full.

Translated from Spansih by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva volunteer

El señor Fausto Gómez vive en casa propia en la zona de Alto Llojeta ladera oeste de la Ciudad de La Paz con su esposa y su tres hijos; el señor Fausto trabaja como empleado en una ladrillería de la zona. Con los créditos anteriores realizaron la compra del terreno y la habilitación de una habitación en la misma. El crédito solicitado será destinado a la construcción una habitación que le dará a sus hijos mayor comodidad principalmente para el desarrollo de sus estudios. Esta es la segunda ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califica favorablemente y puede acceder a un crédito. El crédito anterior ha sido cancelado en su totalidad.

loans.use: Construction of a home

loans.name: Mimin

texts.en: Mimin is 29 years old and has a 10 year old child. She has a small grocery store in which she sells snacks, rice and household goods. She can earn up to US $10 per day. Her husband, D., is employed in the silk-screening business and usually earns US $10 per week.  Sometimes, he helps his wife at the store. Mimin is requesting a IDR 900,000 loan to stock her store with more inventory.  She is willing to repay the loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: to fill her store with more inventory

loans.name: Subgroup B Of Tuwezeshane

texts.en:
Halima, age 42, is married with 4 children (ages 24, 20, 16, and 14). She has had a small café for 10 years and has been selling powered soap and fabrics for 2 years. She starts selling food at her cafe, which is located on someone else’s veranda, from 6am to 2pm daily. She pays the owner a small amount for the use of the veranda, depending on her profit. She charges around 70 cents per plate, making a total of about $5 to $5.50 in profit per day. After 2pm each day, she sells powered soap and fabrics door-to-door, making a profit of around $36 per week. Her children are helping her in these businesses. Her husband has a small business of selling fish and mangoes.

Halima is the leader of Subgroup B of Group Tuwezeshane (Swahili for “Let's help each other”), which totals 24 members. She will be sharing this loan with subgroup members: Lydia V. (sells food), Habiba Z. (sells charcoal), Halima S. (sells food), Regan M. (sells radios), and Clementina N. (sells clothes). Halima and her subgroup have taken 3 previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to enhance their businesses and were able to pay them back successfully.

Halima used the previous loans on her business, which has allowed her to purchase land and start building a 3-roomed house. With the new loan, she hopes to increase her businesses’ stock and to finish the construction of their new home.

In the picture, Halima is in the back row, second from the right.

loans.use: To expand businesses

loans.name: Isah

texts.en: Isah is 33 years old and has a 10 year old child. She earns a living selling coconuts and can earn US $3 per day. Her husband, E., is a laborer who also earns US $3 per day.  Depending on the season, she also sells fruit. She is requesting a IDR 600,000 loan to expand her business.  She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Ani

texts.en: Ani is a 39-year-old mother with an 18-year-old child. She makes a living selling vegetables, and usually earns about $3 per day. Her husband, S., also sells vegetables by going around the village door-to-door and earns $8 per day. Ani has come to us for a loan of $75 to expand her business by buying more vegetables to sell, and will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Chulaimbo Group

texts.en:
Benta A. Opiyo is a 27-year-old mother with 4 children. She operates a retail shop business and has been operating this business for the last 3 years. Benta started this business with start up capital of Ksh 10,000/=.To acquire this start up capital, she had to sell one of the few cows she had and maize that she had harvested. This was a risky venture on her part as cows are a prized possession in this part of the continent. However, her venture paid off and currently the business has a working capital of over Ksh 20,000/=.

Benta's business is located on the outskirts of Kisumu town in an area called Chulaimbo. She hopes to use the money from the loan to increase stock for her business since she feels that there is demand for her products. She hopes that with a larger stock, her profits will increase and she will be able to meet her other needs like paying school fees for her school-going children and replacing the cow she sold to acquire start up capital to start the business. This being a rural set up, the few retail shops in her area are far away from her village and she hopes to take advantage of this to serve clients near her.

She has taken up her leadership role with her sub group with great diligence and ensures that the sub group pays on time and that the group remains united. She has no other source of income as her husband does not earn regular income to fully support the family. This is her first loan with the group.

loans.use: To increase business stock

loans.name: Justina

texts.en: Justina Ikhuozagbe is a hairdresser. She braids s and weaves hair for people living in her community. She is 28 years old, married and lives in Benin City. She has been in business since 2004.She is requesting a loan to buy more weave on, hair creams, relaxer and attachments to sell.

loans.use: To buy more weavon, hair cream and relaxer  for sale.

loans.name: H. Iyah

texts.en: Iyah is 34 years old and has a 10-year-old son. She makes about $15 per week selling household goods at her small shop. Her husband, T., is a farmer who earns $1.50 per day growing and selling his crops. Iyah has applied for a $100 loan to expand her  business by buying more goods to sell to her customers. She will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Masitoh

texts.en: Masitoh is 38 years old and sells snacks and household goods at her small grocery store. She earns about $5 per day while her husband, M., is a laborer who earns $10 per week. Masitoh has applied for a $100 loan to buy more items to sell to her customers. She will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell in her store

loans.name: Nina

texts.en: Nina is 23 years old and has one daughter. She raises chickens near her home, and sells them in local markets when they are fully grown. In a typical month, she earns about $10. Her husband, A., is a worker and usually earns $10 per week. Nina has come to us for a loan of $100 to expand her business by buying more chicks to raise and sell, and will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Nyai

texts.en: Nyai J. is 36 years old and has a 13-year-old daughter. She earns about $20 a day selling snacks and household goods at her small grocery store. Her husband, Jamudin, is a laborer who earns about $1 per day. Nyai has applied for a $125 loan to expand her business by acquiring more items to sell in her store. She will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Uha

texts.en: Uha is 45 years old and makes a living producing and selling cakes. In a typical week, she earns about $20. She usually sells these cakes from a stall in the local market, or by going door-to-door. She is requesting a loan of $75 to produce more cakes, and will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To make more cakes to sell to her customers

loans.name: Jen

texts.en: Jen is a 35-year-old widow who lives with her parents. She runs a beauty salon in her house, and is especially good at applying make-up. In a typical month earns about $40, and uses her income to support her parents as well as herself.  She has applied for a loan of $100 to expand her business, and will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Eroh

texts.en: Eroh is 45 years old and runs a small shop in which she sells vegetables and groceries. She earns about $20 per day. Her husband, A., is a farmer who plants vegetables and earns $30 per month. Eroh has applied for a loan of $100 which she will use to buy more goods to sell in her shop. She will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell in her shop

loans.name: Sati

texts.en: Sati is 44 years old and has one son. She sells snacks and an Indonesian salad called gado-gado at her food stall. She earns about $10 a day doing this, while her husband, T., is laborer and usually earns about $2 per day. Sati has come to us for a loan of $100 to expand her business by buying more items to sell. She will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell in her food stall

loans.name: Siti

texts.en: Siti is 30 years old and has one son. She owns a small store in which she sells snacks and various kinds of groceries. Siti earns about $10 per day while her husband, A., sells fish and usually earns $20 per day. She has come to us for a loan of $75 to buy more items to sell in her store, and will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell in her store

loans.name: Nuryati

texts.en: Nuryati is 34 years old, married and has a 12-year-old child. She makes a living selling flowers, and usually earns about $5 per week. Her husband, I., sells waste and scrap materials and earns $2.50 per day. Nuryati has applied for a loan which she will use to grow more flowers to sell to her customers, and also to expand her husband's business. She will repay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: To grow more flowers to sell to her customers and help expand her husband's business

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
This is 24 year-old Flora M.. She is married to husband Alnord and has one daughter, Monica, who is 7 years old. Flora runs a shop in the rural town of Mlandizi, on the outskirts of Dar es Salaam, where she sells general groceries, such as oil, rice and vegetables and other small items. She requires a loan of $300 to expand the business by purchasing additional stock. Flora thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not credit worthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.pSELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her shop.

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en:
Ashura M.’s business is a flutter of flipping fins and flapping feathers! She owns a small fish farm and also raises chickens which she then kills, plucks, cleans, cuts and sells as meat at market. Ashura is married to husband Selemani with whom she has two children, Asha, 10 and Rahma, 8. She requires a loan of $775 to expand the chicken-raising/killing business and hopes that the vegetarians won’t boycott her loan application!

loans.name: Nsia

texts.en:
Welcome to Nsia S.’s appropriately (and surprisingly) named business: ‘Broiler’ (surprisingly because most businesses in rural areas of Tanzania use Swahili names and broiler is a surprisingly specific English word). Analysis of the name aside, Nsia’s chicken-raising business is a steady one, which she has run since 2006. She now requires a loan of $350 to expand the business in the hope of increasing her profit. Nsia is a single woman who is using her business to support herself and to become financially independent.

texts.en:
Lotions, potions and pills are Mama M.’s speciality. She established the ‘Nekana Medical Store’ in 2004 and now requires a loan of $875 to expand the business by purchasing a larger quantity and range of stock. Nelea is a single mother and the business enables her to support her three children, Natojua, 16, Joseba, 14, and Eliza, 12.

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
This is 25 year-old Mrs. Hadija A.. She is married to husband Shabani with whom she has one son, 5 year-old Warda. Hadija requires a loan of $275 to purchase additional stock for her newly-established business, a shop where she sells various groceries and other small items. She thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
Fish + clothes = fish-tailed skirts? In this case no, although it’s a popular style in Africa! Nuru Lwambo runs two separate businesses, one selling fresh and dried fish, and the other selling clothes. She has operated the businesses since 2000 and 1998 respectively and requires an injection of capital into both in order to increase her stock and sales. Nuru has repaid two previous loans from SELFINA and has proved herself a responsible borrower and businesswoman. She is married to Omali and has two children, Bakari, 10 and Musa, 8. They are also responsible for the care of Omali’s niece Isa, 9.

loans.name: Parmo

texts.en:
Mrs. Parmo M. is a 46 year-old widow, who since 2006 has been supporting herself by selling charcoal. These small, black and dirty pieces of dry earth are important not just to Parmo but to her customers who rely on charcoal to cook their meals. Many Tanzanians still use small coal pots, in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal) and add either paper, dry grass, old plastic bags, or kerosene in order to light them. The fire requires constant fanning to ignite and maintain the flame and makes cooking quite a hot and laborious task. It may not be the easiest or most environmentally friendly form of cooking, but it is the only option many people can afford. Which is good news for Parmo, who requires a loan of $275 in order to add to her stock of mkaa and continue meeting the customer demand.

loans.name: Jorge Luis

texts.es:
I started putting a floor down on the patio of my house because when it rains it floods the walkway. Unfortunately, i don't have the money to finish and thus avoid the humidity that comes into my house and causes sickness in my family, aside from the fact that this pool of water is a breeding ground for infection.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

“Empecé a poner un piso en el patio de mi casa, ya que cuando llueve se hace una laguna he impide el paso, desafortunadamente me falto dinero para terminar de ponerlo y así evitar que en esta temporada haya tanta humedad en mi vivienda y provoque enfermedades a mi familia, aparte de que el estancamiento de esa agua es un foco de infección $ 1,000.00 dlls para terminar de poner el piso en el patio de mi vivienda.

loans.use: To finish putting down a floor on the patio of my house.

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Thirty-seven year old Salma R. is a busy woman. She is married and a mother of three, Hussein, 10, Mussa, 7, and Hassani, 5. She is employed by the Tanzanian Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs as an Assistant Registration Officer and also runs three businesses! In 2000 she began selling bags of concrete and in 2004 added the sale of soda to her ventures. This year Salma opened a shop from which to sell her goods, to which she added a variety of building materials such as steel, gravel and pebbles. She requires a loan of $1,050.00 to further establish and expand this business by purchasing additional stock in bulk. Salma has successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA and is determined to do so again.

texts.en:

In 2002, she established a business selling raw rice and now requires a loan of $525 in order to purchase additional stock and expand her business. Jane has already successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA and plans to do so again.

loans.name: Bertha

texts.en:
After over ten years in the agricultural sector, Bertha W. is making the leap to the service sector. She plans to open a stationery shop that will also offer secretarial and printing services, and she requires a loan of $600 to purchase a computer and printer. Her business will be an interesting and useful additional to the rural town of Kiluvia Madukani (about 20km out of Dar es Salaam), where such services are not readily available.

Bertha is a single mother of three, Emmanuel, 15, Catherine, 14 and Erick, 8, and she hopes that her business will enable her to support her young family.

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en:
This is Tereza M.. She is 40 years old and married to Zabron, with whom she has one daughter, Lucia, 20. Since 2006, Tereza has run a ‘mgahawa’ (restaurant). The mgahawa is popular with locals and visitors alike and serves local dishes such as rice, beans, plantain (a savoury cooked banana), ugali (maize porridge), meat and vegetables, with a range of sauces. Tereza requires a loan of $450 in order to purchase stock, such as sodas and ingredients, in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

texts.en:
This is 38 year-old Asumpta F.. She is a single mother of two, Jacqueline, 14 and Geofrey, 8. In 2005, Asumpta established a business raising and selling chickens. She is feeling clucky again and is requesting a loan of $1,050.00 in order to purchase additional chicks and extend their enclosure. Asumpta is a long-standing and reliable SELFINA client, having already repaid three loans. She looks forward to continually expanding her business.

loans.name: Mboni

texts.en:
“Kuku, kuku, kuku!” (chickens, chickens, chickens!) I exclaimed to my colleague. “Why is everyone selling kuku?! I’m sick of writing about kuku and Kiva lenders are probably sick of reading about them!” Not understanding that I just wanted to vent and that it was a rhetorical question, one of the earnest young men from IT gave me a serious analysis of the reasons why so many of our clients choose to raise and sell chickens. Firstly, they require little start-up capital, you can start with one or two and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiple naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising chickens is so popular (maybe they are friendlier than other animals? Prettier?), but that was as deep as time would allow our analysis to go.

I imagine that some, if not all, of these factors encouraged Mboni M. to establish her kuku-raising business in 2005. She now requires a loan of $275 to purchase even more kuku and expand her business. Mboni is married to Henry and has one daughter, Erica, who is 4 years-old.

Since 2003, Mama Rich has run a grocery store in the rural town of Mailimoja, where she sells fruit and vegetables, rice, oil, and countless other food and non-food items. She requires a loan of $875 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Asked what kind of business she runs, Lucia M. replied “biashara ndogo ndogo”, which literally translated (from Swahili) means "business, small, small”. This probably gives you a good idea of the business, which is a small kiosk from which Lucia sells candy, cigarettes, peanuts, phone credit, and a few other bits and bobs. She is requesting a loan of $450 to expand this business by purchasing additional stock. Lucia is married to Christopher, with whom she has two children, Irene, 4 and Meema, 1. She thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Godbelther

texts.en:
This is Mama Jack (in reference to her eldest child and probably safer than using her real name, for which I can provide no translation or explanation!). Mama Jack makes and sells women’s clothing, usually long, flowing, kaftan-like dresses, made from beautiful batik cloth (what is often referred to as tie-dyed in the west). She requires a loan of $700 to purchase bulk bundles of plain cloth, as well as different dyes with which to create her creative creations! Mama Jack has already repaid one loan from SELFINA. She is married to Mchukya and has three children, Jackline, 9, Godfrey, 7 and Grace, 3.

loans.name: Adidiata

texts.en: Adidiata O. is a 41-year-old single mother. She has 3 children and lives with them in Attecoube, a populated suburb in the north-west area of the Abidjan district. She sells fruits and vegetables in the Attecoube market to care for herself and her children who all go to school. Her two elder children are both in a public grammar school, and her younger daughter will finish primary school next year. She is a hard worker and has been able to care for her family with the profits from her fruits and vegetables business. She purchases her goods in the wholesale market in Bingerville, a village near Abidjan, and retails them in the Attecoube market. She has been in the AE&I microcredit program for two years and has been an excellent performer.

loans.use: Adidiata Ouattara will use the loan to purchase goods.

loans.name: Marcelline Lewei

texts.en: Marcelline is 41 years old. She has been a widow since 2005 and has 3 children. She faced a very hard situation when she lost her husband. Her children are still very young, and she has to care for them alone in a very difficult and tight environment. Her elder daughter is in grammar school, and the two younger children are in primary school. Marcelline has demonstrated a fighting spirit to face the situation. AE&I microcredit program has been a crucial supporting resource for Marcelline, who has obtained different loans to relaunch her business. She sells various aromatic products and cereals in the Yopougon market, a suburb in the north of the Abidjan district. She will use the loan to purchase goods in bulk.

loans.use: Marcelline Lewei Akpa will use the loan to purchase goods.

loans.name: Allangba Jeannette

texts.en: Jeannette is a 60-year-old woman. Jeannette sells spices and condiments in the Yopougon-Nouveau Quartier market in the north of Abidjan. She has been in this business for more than 20 years. Her husband is a coffee and cocoa farm worker in Ouragahio, 260 miles from Abidjan. She is the main resources provider for their household expenses. Jeannette has been in the AE&I microcredit program for 3 years and has performed very well since then.

loans.use: To purchase goods

loans.name: María Elizabeth

texts.es:
Sra. Elizabeth is a member of the Communal Bank "Las Activas". She lives in the housing project Gentleman of Miracles, Pachacutec MzMLt. 06, Calleria district in the state of Ucayali. She is 31 years old, and the mother of 3 children. Her husband is a driver, but his income is not enough to cover their housing costs. For this reason, Maria Elizabeth, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos of S/300.00 (US$100.00) decided to start a small business (sale of chickens).

Currently she has a small shop where she sells chickens (birds for consumption). She gets up at 1:00A.M. to go and purchase her products, and at 5:00A.M. opens her store. The store usually closes at 1:00P.M., when she returns to her home to make lunch for her small children. Later she rests and prepares for the next day's routine.

With this loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.1,000 (US$334.00 approx.), which will be repaid in 5 months, she will increase her regular purchase of chickens (she will purchase 70 chickens a day), to increase her sales and earn more income.

Maria Elizabeth is happy to have three healthy children, and to see her business prosper, since it is a very important job for her, as it allows her to achieve the wellbeing of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Elizabeth pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Activas”, vive en el Asentamiento Humano Señor de los Milagros Jr. Pachacutec Mz M Lt. 06, del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 31 años de edad y es madre de 3 hijos, su esposo es motocarrista, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos del hogar, es así que Maria Elizabeth, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decide poner un pequeño negocio (venta de pollos). En la actualidad cuenta con un pequeño puesto de venta de pollos (aves de consumo). Se levanta a la 1 de la mañana para ir a comprar sus productos y a las 5 a.m. empieza la atención en su puesto. La venta normalmente termina a las 1 p.m., luego se dirige a su domicilio para hacer el almuerzo de sus pequeños hijos para después descansar y prepararse para la rutina del día siguiente. Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,000 (US$ 334.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 5 meses, incrementara la compra habitual de pollos (comprará 70 pollos diarios), para que su venta pueda aumentar y de esa manera tener mayores ingresos. Maria Elizabeth está muy contenta de tener sanos a sus 3 hijos y ver que su negocio prospera, ya que es un logro muy importante para ella, así alcanza el bienestar de su familia.

loans.use: To purchase chickens for consumption

loans.name: Marita Astra

texts.es:
Mrs. Marita is part of the communal bank “Las Fresitas”, lives at Jr. Los Cedros Mz. 265 Lt. 3, District of Yarina Cocha, Ucayali Province. She’s 42 years old and is the mother of 3 children, of whom only one still depends on her. She’s married and her husband works, but the income isn’t enough to cover the costs of the house. This is why Marita, with the 1st loan she received of 300 soles ($100US) from Manuela Ramos, started a bakery and bought a second hand motorcar to increase the household income.

In fact, she bakes in the bakery she started in her house and delivers it with her motorcar. She and her husband wake up at 4am to knead the dough so they can be ready to distribute and sell it to their customers by 6am. Afterwards, she makes breakfast for her sons so they can go to their respective jobs and schools.

With the recent loan she received from Manuela Ramos of 3000 soles ($1000US approx.) -- which will be repaid in 6 months -- she‘ll buy 1 bag of flour, 1 box of butter, 3 packs of yeast, half a bag of sugar, 2 packs of large sodas and two packs of small sodas, and also some parts for her motorcar. Marita is happy because she feels that all her dreams are being made into a reality. Thanks to the support of Manuela Ramos, her business is growing, her clients are satisfied with her products, and her income is growing more and more every day. Along with their children, they’re going to make the business prosper and grow for the wellbeing of the whole family.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

. La señora Marita pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Fresitas”, vive en Jr. Los Cedros Mz. 265 Lt. 3, del distrito de Yarina Cocha del departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 42 años y es madre de 3 hijos, de los cuales dos ya son mayores de edad y uno aun depende de ella. Está casada, su esposo es empleado, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos de la casa, es así que Marita, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decide poner una panadería y comprar un motocar de segunda, para poder tener mas ingresos económicos en su familia. En la actualidad cuenta con una pequeña panadería que instaló en su propia casa y útiliza el motocar para distribuir sus panes. Ella y su esposo se levantan a las 4.00 de la mañana para amasar el pan y que estén listos a las 6 para poder repartirlos y venderlos a sus clientes, después hace el desayuno de sus hijos para que puedan ir a sus respectivos centros de trabajo y estudios. Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 3,000 (US$ 1003.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará 1 saco de harina, 1 caja de manteca, 3 paquetes de levadura, 2 bolsas de mejorador, ½ saco de azúcar, 2 paquetes de gaseosas grandes y dos cajas de gaseosas chicas, y también comprará piezas para su motocar. Marita está muy feliz porque siente que todos sus anhelos se están realizando gracias al apoyo de Manuela Ramos, su negocio crece, sus clientes están satisfechos con sus productos y las ganancias aumentan cada día más y más. Junto a sus hijos van a hacer que el negocio prospere y crezca mas para su propio bienestar familiar.

loans.use: To buy ingredients.  To buy soda.  To buy motorcar parts.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.es:
Mrs. Ruth belongs to the Communal Bank of Virtuous Women, she lives at 613 Jr. Pachitea in the district of Calleria in the region of Ucayali. She is 48 years old and the mother of 5 children, all are independents. Her husband is a businessman, but his income does not cover the family expenses, and because of this Ruth, and with the first loan received from Manuela Ramos of $100 she decided to start a small business of buying and selling clothing and shoes. Nowadays, she has her business of buying and selling shoes (for women, men and children). Her merchandise is of good quality and priced in agreement with the range of the economy of the people of Ucayali. With the recently received loan from Manuela Ramos of $669, that will be paid in 6 months, she will buy clothes of all models, brands and sizes, shoes in all sizes and undergarments. Ruth is a woman who is very entrepreneurial and a fighter, with desires to persevere instead of letting herself become overwhelmed by the obstacles that may arise in daily life and in her business. Ruth feels very content to be a partner with Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Ruth pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Virtuosas, vive en Jr. Pachitea 613, del distrito D. Calleria del departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 48 años y es madre D. 5 hijos, todos independientes. Su esposo es comerciante, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos familiares, es así que Ruth, con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/ 300.00 (US$100.00) deciD. poner un pequeño negocio D. compra y venta D. ropa y zapatos. En la actualidad, mantiene su negocio D. compra y venta D. zapatos (para damas, caballeros y niños). Su mercadería es D. muy buena calidad y con precios acorD. al alcance D. la economía D. los ucayalinos. Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 2,000 (US$ 669.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará ropa D. todos los modelos, marcas y tallas, zapatos en todas las tallas y ropa interior. Ruth es una mujer muy emprendedora y luchadora, con ganas D. salir adelante sin dejarse vencer por los obstáculos que se puedan presentar en la vida cotidiana como en su negocio. Ruth se siente muy contenta D. pertenecer a Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: To purchase clothing and footwear.

loans.name: Lagos 4 Group

texts.es:
PASCUALA dedicates her time to the craftsmanship of skirts and blouses. She also makes pillowcases, shawls, serviettes, and tablecloths with typical designs from the region. She is 37 years old, has been married for 12 years and her husband is a florist, cultivating and selling. In general, almost the entire group is dedicated to artisanal work, as it’s in demand in the region, by the tourists who visit.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

PASCUALA, se dedica al bordado de faldas y blusas artesanales , también hace cojines , chales , servilletas y manteles todos con bordados típicos de la zona.Ella tiene 37 años, esta casada hace 12 años y su esposo se dedica al cultivo y comercio de flores. En general casi todo el grupo esta dedicado a los trabajos artesanales ya que en la zona que ellas viven los productos bordados son muy cotizados por los turistas que visitan la zona .

loans.use: TO BUY MATERIALS LIKE THREAD AND FABRIC.

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en: Mrs. Khiev T., age 47, works with her husband on her plantation growing crops, making around $4 each day. They have five children, three who are employed at a garment factory, and two who are students. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase a cow to help her plow her field. This will lead to a greater output of crops and increase the family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for her farm.

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Mrs. Ven S. L., age 45, is a vendor in the market earning about $2 per day. Her husband makes $2 per day by driving a horse-cart to transport passengers. They have five children, two who are married and live away from home and three who are students living at home. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase to purchase a new horse. Their current horse is sick and cannot work, so their income has been cut in half. She will use the loan to purchase a horse to continue her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchase a horse to operate a horse-cart business.

loans.name: Thaong

texts.en: Mrs. Thaong C., age 25, is a vendor at a market, earning around $3 each day. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning $5 per day. They have one child who is a student. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase more construction tools for her husband to expand his business and increase the family’s income. She is pictured with her husband.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools.

loans.name: Thi Ly

texts.vi:
Ms Lý was born in 1951, she has 4 children. Her main occupation is selling music CDs & tapes. This is the main income for her family. Her husband works in construction. She never had received a loan before because she could not qualify for one: either because she has no collateral or the interest rate is too high or the minimum loan amount is too much ... She is very happy when she learns of BinhMinh fund (SEDA), she wishes to obtain a loan to buy more CDs & tapes.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Lý sinh năm 1951, có 4 con. Hiện tại chị đang kinh doanh băng đĩa. Đây là công việc chính tạo thu nhập cho gia đình. Chồng chị làm thợ xây cũng hỗ trợ được cho gia đình. Từ trước đến nay, chị chưa tvay vốn từ tổ chức nào vì chị không đáp ứng được các yêu cầu cho vay của họ như phải thế chấp, khoản vay phải lớn, lãi suất cao.... Chị rất vui mừng khi tiếp cận được với chương trình tài chính vi mô Binhminh và mong muốn sớm được nhận vốn vay.

loans.use: To purchase discs & tapes

loans.name: Thi Ly

texts.vi: Chị Lý sinh năm 1951, có 4 con. Hiện tại chị đang kinh doanh băng đĩa. Đây là công việc chính tạo thu nhập cho gia đình. Chồng chị làm thợ xây cũng hỗ trợ được cho gia đình. Từ trước đến nay, chị chưa tvay vốn từ tổ chức nào vì chị không đáp ứng được các yêu cầu cho vay của họ như phải thế chấp, khoản vay phải lớn, lãi suất cao.... Chị rất vui mừng khi tiếp cận được với chương trình  tài chính vi mô Binhminh và mong muốn sớm được nhận vốn vay.

loans.use: To purchase discs & tapes

loans.name: Thi Ha

texts.vi:
Ms Hà is married and has a young child. They live in the town of Chờ, Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh. Before she used to be a garment contractor making blankets, pillows ...etc. Then she opened a store to sell those herself. Her husband is a woodworker and the main breadwinner in the family. Ms Hà wishes to obtain a loan to invest in her store.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hà đã có chồng và 1 con nhỏ. Chị sống ở Thị trấn Chờ, Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh. Trước đây, chj nhận may thuê chăn, gối... cho các cửa hàng. Sau này, chi đã tích cóp và mở được một cửa hàng bán chăn, ga, gối, đệm cho riêng mình. Chồng chị làm thợ mộc và là người tạo thu nhập chính cho gia đình. Chị rất mong có thêm vốn để mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của mình.

loans.use: To purchase pillow, blanket for sale

loans.name: Thi Hoa

texts.vi:
Ms Hoa was recently married and expecting her first child. She owns a small store selling hats. Every week, she and her husband go to Hà Nội to pick up the merchandise. If they buy hats in big quantity, they would get better prices. For this reason, Hoa really wishes to have more capital to invest in her business. Her husband is a construction worker. She will pay back the loan with the revenue from her store.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hoa vừa xây dựng gia đình và sắp có con. Chị có cửa hàng bán mũ gần nhà. Hàng tuấn, hai vợ chồng lại đi Hà Nội lấy mũ về bán. Nếu lấy mũ với số lượng nhiều thì chị sẽ được hưởng giá ưu đãi hơn. Do đó, chị rất mong có thêm vốn để tăng số lượng hàng lấy về. Chồng chị là công nhân xây dựng cũng có thu nhập giúp cho gia đình. Thu nhập để hoàn vốn cũng chính là từ việc kinh doanh mũ của chị.

loans.use: To purchase more hats for sale

loans.name: Bashorat

texts.en: Bashorat T. lives in Khujand, Tajikistan.   She is married and has 3 children.  She has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2006.  She trades in the Friday and Sunday bazaar. She has a good assortment of  women's suits and coats that she sells. Working in this business, she has competitors so now she requires a loan of $300 for increased purchases and business development. Bashorat intends to purchase inter-season coats which she hopes will make her business more successful.

loans.use: To purchase inter-season coats

loans.name: Bashorat

texts.en: Bashorat T. lives in Khujand; she is married and has 3 children.  She is an active client of MicroInvest from 2006. The statistic indicator shows the permanent loan sum increase that says about the business development and business stability. She trades in Friday and Sunday bazaar. She has the good assortment and she is working in the woman suits and mantles selling. Working in this sphere she has the competitors so now she requires the loan in 1000 STJ for the good purchase and business development. She is attended to purchase the inter-season mantles that she is going to realize successfully.

loans.use: the good purchase

loans.name: Inom

texts.en: Inom M. lives in Khujand, Tajikistan. He is married and has 3 children.  He became a client of MicroInvest this year but already has recommended himself as a serious and executive client. He trades in the bazaar where his shop selling women's and menswear is located. Inom has a good assortment of goods.. Working in this sphere, he has competitors so he requires a loan of $300 for the purchase of more winter goods  This will allow Inom to improve the business' conditions and to increase the assortment of clothing that he sells.

loans.use: To purchase winter goods

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en: Maryam H.  has been one of the most active clients of Microinvest since2003. During this time she has showed herself to be an honest and responsible person.She is divorced and she alone supports 8 children. A daily living wage is low and it is really difficult to earn money for such big family,but Maryam is very strong and tolerant women. She has trained her children to be kind and helpful to each other.  Today some of them are old enough to help; her two elder sons help  with the  transportation of  her goods from Uzbekistan.and her daughter sells her goods at her trade place. For the coming holiday trade Maryam wants to increase her assortment and also she wants to include some Holiday goods such as New Year cards and other presents.She hopes to receive  extra capital from KIVA lenders.

loans.use: Purchase of next batch of perfumes and additional holiday cards and other presents.

loans.name: Mukhae

texts.en: Mukhae A. lives in Khujand, Tajikistan. She is married and has 3 children. She works sellng  national-styled and European-styled coats and suits in a commericial business. She is one of the active clients of MicroInvest.  Working in  suit and coat wear, Mukhae requires special furniture and materials (material for the seasonal suit making) that make a product of high quality. Having a lot of interesting ideas now, Mukhae A. requests the loan for the winter material purchase and its future usage in suit making.

loans.use: for  winter material purchase

loans.name: Lutfy

texts.en: Lutfy J. lives in Khujand, Tajikistan. She is married and has 5 children. She works in the Joint-Stock Company “Navbakhor” in the commercial industry of the national-styled and european-styled wear. She is an active client of MicroInvest and the statistics indicate  an income increase and business stability. Now Lutfy requires a loan  of $175 for a special furniture purchase because she is a very skilled seamstress. Working in wear making she requires special furniture that makes the produced goods more qualitative and engaging.

loans.use: Special furniture purchase

loans.name: Hosiyat

texts.en: Hosiyat K. is a very cheerful woman. She always smiles a happy smile.She is a kind person and the mother of 3 children. Her business located is in the J.Rasulov food market in Tadjikistan. Hosiyat's husband is a worker on a collective farm and supports her in her activity. 17 years ago he gave her money to start her business. He also helped her to rent a trading  place in the market. She started her business from selling cookies and other confectionery products from local confectionery workshops.Gradually she has increased her working capital and has included several kinds of candy to her assortment .Today Hosiyat has a fast turnover of her goods and she is requesting from KIva lenders extra capital to increase her assortment  of candies before the New Year holiday.

loans.use: Increasing the volume of goods before New Year.

loans.name: Zulfy

texts.en: Zulfy K. lives in Khujand; she is married and has 4 children. She has been an active and strongly motivated client of MicroInvest since 2005 . Her credit record qualifies her for new and and larger loans. She trades in the Panjshanbe bazaar where her shop is located. She sells an assortment of clothing, including children's clothing. She would like to branch out into selling leather goods, and she is asking for a loan of $475 to buy leather jackets.

loans.use: To buy leather jackets for resale

loans.name: Asiah

texts.en: I am Asiah S. A. from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan.  I am the mother of three children, two boys and one girl. My husband works at a local company for meager pays while I am a seamstress. I have been in this business for last ten years and I have been performing very well. I request a loan of $500 to expand my business. I plan to buy cloth, threads and sequins with this money in bulk to save money.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Sughran

texts.en: I am Sughran Q. from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I am married with eight children. My husband has had a scrap store for last few years. Last year he took a loan for his business and successfully repaid it.  He now desires to expand his business. He will buy scrap items in bulk. Therefore, I request a loan of $350 to invest in my husband’s business.

loans.use: To expand scrap business

loans.name: Wafaa

texts.en: Wafaa is a 51 year old widow who lives in the Beirut suburbs in the region of Borj el Barajneh. Wafaa is a seamstress who is doing her best to support herself with the income she is generating from her business. She needs a loan of $300 to purchase the basic materials required for her tailoring business.

loans.use: to purchase the basic materials required for her tailoring business

loans.name: Shabana

texts.en: I am Shabana S. from Lahore, a busy metropolitan in Pakistan. I am a mother of two children, one girl and one boy. My daughter studies in grade three  while my son studies in grade two. I embroider shawls and my husband is an auto spare parts dealer. Last year we took a loan for our spare parts business to increase our income. We earned a reasonable rate of return and bought a television and fridge for our home. My husband feels that he should further expand his business for which he requests a loan of $500.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en: Zeinab is a 55 year old widow with two children. She lives with her family in the Beirut suburbs in the region of Borj el Barajneh. Zeinab is a seamstress who is doing her best to support her family with the income she is generating from her business. She needs a loan of $300 to purchase the basic materials required for her tailoring business.

loans.use: to purchase the basic materials required for her tailoring business

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en: My name is Shamim A. and I am 36, married with four children. I live with my family in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. My husband is a blacksmith and I embroider clothes on order. I have been doing embroidery for last eight years and I have expertise in my work.  I plan on starting my own embroidered clothes business for which I will need to invest in good quality fabric and equipment. Please lend me $250 for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy good quality fabric

loans.name: Kaltoum

texts.en: Kaltoum is a 39 year old woman who lives in the Beirut suburbs in the region of Borj el Barajneh. Kaltoum owns a grocery shop which is her only source of income. Kaltoum suffers from a physical handicap and is striving to support herself through her business. She needs $400 to purchase enough merchandise for her store. Kaltoum is a remarkable woman who is determined to stay independent.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise

loans.name: Mokhy

texts.en: Mokhy F. lives in B.Gafurov, Tajikistan. She is married and has 4 children.  She has been an active client of MicroInvest  since 2002.  She trades in the  bazaar “Samy Rakhmon” where her pharmacy is located. She has a large assortment of products so she has permanent clients. Here one may find medicines at an affordable price. But nevertheless, continued investment is required so Mokhy requests a loan to expand her business and to keep up with her medicine turnover rate.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en: I am Parveen A. from Lahore, a big city in Pakistan. I am married with three children, all of whom attend school. I am a housewife and my husband makes and sells shoes. He is the only breadwinner of the entire family. We are finding it hard to manage our household expenses and we feel the need of an extra income. Please lend us $350 to invest in our shoe business.
