Mrs. Yem S., 42, is married with three children and lives in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. To support the household, she works raising pigs at her home, while her husband works transporting and selling wood to the rest of the province, earning together around $6/day of profit.
Mrs. Yem S. has applied for a loan to purchase more feed for her livestock and the remainder of the money is to buy a cow for her husband which he will use as transportation for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more feeds for her livestock and the remainder of the money is to buy a cow for her husband

loans.name: Aka Suzanne

texts.en: Suzanne is a 51-year-old dynamic woman. She has sold various condiments and spices since 1995 when she lost her job as a typist in a governmental agency. She has 3 children: 2 daughters who are married and a son who is unemployed. Her husband is retired from the public transportation company. His revenue is not sufficient to cover the household expenses. Suzanne's revenue from her business is therefore an important resource for her family. She wants to develop her business by diversifying her products offered, especially cooked food. Suzanne is dynamic and honest.

loans.use: To purchase goods in bulk

loans.name: Chem

texts.en: Mrs. Chem C. L., 25, is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. In order to supplement her household, Mrs.Chem C. works selling rice crops at a market, making on average about $2/day of profit. Her husband, 27, meanwhile, works as a construction foreman and generally earns around $3/day of profit. Mrs. Chhem C. would like to use this loan to purchase a motorcycle so that she doesn’t have to use a motor-taxi as her business’s transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle so that she doesn’t longer use a motor-taxi for their business’s transportation.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Chem Chhun Lay has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increase on her stock.

loans.name: Huy

texts.en: Mrs. Huy N., 49, is married with six children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work on their piece of land growing cucumber and raising pigs, earning collectively around $2/day. Three of her children are currently enrolled in school and the rest are too young. This couple has recently requested for a loan to expand their livestock by adding more pigs and feed.

loans.use: To expand her livestock by adding more pigs and feeds.

payments.comment: Congratulations !!! now Mrs. Huy Neang is able to pay off her loan very early and now she plans to take out another loan to keep expanding her livestock. Thanks for your loan to expand and support her family's livelyhood.

loans.name: Thai

texts.en: Mrs. Thai H., aged 50, grows rice on a plot of land and earns about $1 a day selling her crops at the local market.  A widow, she supports her four children with this business.  Two of her children are students, while the other two are employed at a garment factory and make about $70 each a month.  She would like to request a loan of $500 to purchase more seeds to increase crop yields.  In the future she would like to reinvest the additional earnings generated by this loan  back into her business and purchase a hand-tractor to increase the efficiency of her rice cultivation.  She plans to use the increased income to help fund her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase more seeds to increase crop yields.

loans.name: Pnov

texts.en: Mrs. Pnov M., 36, is a mother of four children and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham, province, Cambodia. She and her husband work producing and selling palm sugars to the people in their community, earning collectively around $4/day in revenue. Two of her children, therefore, are currently employed at a garment factory making $80/month each and the rest of whom one is student and another one is too young. Mrs. Pnov M. hope to use this loan to purchase a plot of farmland to grow rice crops and wide variety of vegetables in order to raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of farmland to grow rice crops and wide variety of vegetables in order to raise her standard of living

loans.name: Tano Lucie

texts.en:
Lucie is a 36-year-old single mother. She lives with her 7-year-old son in Yopougon, a populated suburb in the north of Abidjan. Lucie has sold various aromas, spices, and grilled fish and meat in the Yopougon-Sicogi market for many years to care for herself and her son. She was abandoned by her cohabitant 3 months after the birth of her son.

Her business has allowed her to send her son to elementary school this year. She is seeking a loan to purchase a deep freezer container to store fresh meat and fish.

loans.use: To purchase goods

loans.name: Hudoiberdieva

texts.ru:
M. Hudoiberdieva, age 45, has three children. She works in the local hospital as an optometrist nurse while her husband works as a taxi driver. Her oldest daughter has just turned 18 and is getting married but the family does not have enough money for the wedding. That is why she has applied for this loan.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Матлюба, возраст45 лет, имеет троих детей. Работает в районой поликлинике глазной медсестрой ,муж работает наемным водителем на маршрутном такси.Старшей дочери исполнилось 18 лет , ее выдают замуж.Но для проведения свадебного мероприятия у семьи не хватает финансов . поэтому она , Матлюба Худойбердиева решила кредитоваться в Микроинвесте.

loans.use: wedding cost

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Check out that warm smile. That’s the real thing! Edward is the proud owner of the Glory Hardware Store in Lugazi, a village half way between Zampala and Jinji, the source of the Nile. Lugazi is one of those special places where life doesn’t go too fast and everyone knows everyone. You can walk down the middle of the street and the only thing coming your way will be children and other pedestrians.

In his well organized hardware store, which he has operated for six years, Edward sells cement, nails, paint, chain, rope, wire, etc. He has a very good location, smiles and laughs easily, and is very friendly to everyone. He is married with 4 children and he also cares for 3 orphans. With his loan, he plans to buy more cement and hardware for his store. There are no concrete trucks to deliver large quantities of concrete, so cement in bags is mixed with sand and gravel to build even large commercial buildings. So, hardware stores can sell large quantities of cement.

loans.use: Edward plans to use his loan to buy more cement and hardware for his store.

loans.name: Lalezar

texts.en:
Lalezar is a low-income vulnerable woman. She is 53, married and lives in the village of Saatli in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region.
Lalezar owns a herd of milk cows. Every day she sells milk to the local milk-processing shop. Her son and daughter-in-law (she is pictured) help her to breed cows in the nearby grazing field. The income from four cows is too low to support the family and to increase number of cows. That’s why Lalezar applied to the Norwegian Microcredit Saatli branch for a $500 loan to buy one more calf  to make her monthly income higher. The price of  a milk calf is $300; cost of breeding is $100. The other $100 she plans to save for unexpected expenditures.

loans.use: To buy a pedigree calf

loans.name: Rasheed Un Nisa

texts.en:
I request a loan of $900 for my husband’s rickshaw workshop and spare parts business. He has made a small cabin within his workshop to sell these spare parts. Earlier, he was a rickshaw driver then, about 15 years ago he decided to start a workshop of his own to increase his income and fulfil his dream of running his own workshop. He buys spare parts from the spare parts market here in Lahore, Pakistan. A couple of years ago, he acquired loans for his business which turned out into increased profits and enabled us to repair our house. My husband works very hard to grow his business by leaps and bounds.
I am a mother of four girls and four boys. Two of my daughters are married and my elder son helps his father in the business. We hope that by investing your loan in our business, we will turn out even better profits, which we will save for when our children marry.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts in bulk to expand our business

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en: I am Naseem L. from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I was married eight years ago and I have two sons. My elder son is five years old and attends kindergarten whereas the younger one is two years old and will hopefully attend school in the future. My husband and I make and sell Rickshaw (three-wheeled taxi) indicator lights. We have been in this business for more than five years. He obtains orders from various rickshaw factories and supplies them with the required lights. However we do not have the necessary funds to fulfill large orders. Therefore, we require a loan of $575 to increase and expand our business.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Suubilyamukama Lending Group

texts.en:
Aisha is the Chairperson for the Suubilyamukama Lending Group in the Lugazi Village. (Yes, I did double-check the name of the lending group, but I will leave it to you for the correct pronunciation.) Since Lugazi is in a very rural area, most of the members are in agriculture. Aisha is an exception. When I asked her what her business was she told me she was a “hawker”.

Once I understood what she was saying, I still had a problem with the word, since in my culture it is often deemed a business that has illegal connotations. But I did not want to change the word, since this is what she said, so let me clarify. A hawker is someone who sells there goods without the benefit of a fixed location. They therefore walk around busy markets and taxi parks carrying and selling their wares. Aisha sells used clothing. This is not an easy job and most would like to be able to afford to rent a store front. There are many hawkers on the streets and they are seen as just as respectable as storefront owners, though not as well off.

Aisha has been a hawker for two years and a member of her lending group for nine years, hence her position as chairperson. I got the feeling she has had a downturn in her life, but is determined to be able to rent a storefront. She is married and has three children. With her portion of the group loan, which is approximately $275 US, she plans to buy more used clothing to sell. The clothing is bought in Kampala and is bought in bags or bales. She is not allowed to see what is in the bags until after she purchases it, though she can determine if she wants t-shirts or shirts or skirts. There can be several hundred items in each bale.

loans.use: Aisha plans to use her loan to buy more bales of used clothing to sell.

loans.name: Zoharan

texts.en: I am a widow with nine children: seven sons and two daughters. My children had to quit their studies at very early ages due to the financial repercussions we had to face after their father’s death. But all of my sons did not lose heart and worked very hard to earn a better living for themselves.  My daughters are married and are happy with their families. Two of my sons together run a food stall in one of the more crowded markets of the city. They are able to make a profit of $400 a month. They posses a strong client base and now they want to add few more items to their restaurant for which they require a loan of $500

loans.use: Expand food stall

loans.name: Milly

texts.en:
Sometimes it’s quite difficult to get to a client and it’s easier to take the picture in town. We do try to get to their business, but when it comes to agriculture, the farm may be several hours walk on a narrow path through dense vegetation. The villagers really want you to come to their homes, and with some people you just can’t say “no”. Milly is one of those special people to whom you just can’t say “no”. And if you did, you know you would have missed out on something special.

So, off we went. It took about an hour. We passed by many rural mud and twig huts, passing lots of children and lots of small individual plots of land. This is sustenance farming: plots that grow a few banana trees, with sweet potatoes between, some cassava, beans, a coffee plant, yams, etc. Most have no income, no job, but the land is fertile. Most have chickens but rarely can one afford a cow, pig or goat.

Milly’s pride is her cow. Actually she has two cows. The one in the picture is old and gives less milk now. Conversations with neighbors tend to be about how your cow is doing and how much milk did you get yesterday, etc. Milly’s daughter and her family live next to Milly. There are many children. We passed by a corral where a small child was resting under the shade. Milly told me that this was her granddaughter and that she had broken her leg three months ago. Her leg was twisted and allowed to heal in place.

Milly wants to trade her old cow for a newer one that will produce more milk. For now, she will use her loan to buy food and medicine for her cows.

loans.use: Milly plans to use her loan to buy food and medicine for her cows.

loans.name: Asma

texts.en: I am Asma H. from Lahore, Pakistan. I was married two years ago and I have a daughter who is only five days old. I work with my husband at his bangles store that he has been running for the past six years. Selling bangles is our family business and it is a very profitable business. Eid is around the corner and we need to buy a greater stock of bangles for the store. We need $575 as a loan. I have a savings account where I save money for my child to give her a better future

loans.use: To buy jewellery stock

loans.name: Jannet

texts.en:
Jannet is 53, married with 7 children, and she cares for 6 orphaned relatives. As I have written in other stories, most people take care of orphans. In Jannet’s case these are her grandchildren. Several of her children have died.

Uganda was one of the hardest hit African nations when it came to the AIDS epidemic. In the late 1990’s it is believed that almost one in three person’s in the capitol city of Kampala had HIV/AIDS. To its credit, Uganda has done one of the best jobs of reducing the number to around 5.6% as of 2005. But the effect of the epidemic is that there is a whole generation “missing”. In Uganda, there are old people and young people, but noticeably fewer middle aged people. Half the population of Uganda is under the age of 15 and the birth rate is one of the highest in the world.

Jannet has a retail shop and four cows which are cross breeds. Cross breeds tend to be less prone to disease and give more milk. With her loan she plans to buy 4 pigs and to add cooking oil, sugar, maize flour, and sauce pans to her shop. Her dream is to one day buy a plot of land and build some rental houses.

loans.use: With her loan, Jannet plans to buy 4 pigs and to add cooking oil, maize flour, and saucepans to her retail store.

loans.name: Shazia Mohd

texts.en: I am Shazia Mohd N.. I was married two years ago. I work at a beauty salon and my husband makes embroidered clothes. He runs a shop in one of the bigger markets of the city and has two workers to help him in his work. He has been in this business for 15 years and has worked very hard for its growth.  These days due to upcoming holidays he is getting bigger orders and he needs a loan to fulfill them promptly. Please lend him $575 for this purpose. I also plan to open up my own salon sometime in the future.

loans.use: In order to fulfil larger orders

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 39, married with 5 children, and she cares for 4 orphans. Easy to smile, Josephine enjoyed showing me her line of clothes and the material which she uses to make them. She is a tailor and she sews traditional African wear, with a Nigerian accent. She specializes in making the traditional Gomesi dress, worn for special occasions and by elderly women as a sign of respect. She also has a line of jewelry. She has been in business for nine years.

Josephine has a pleasing business nature. She is quite sociable, has a positive outlook and is liked by all. She has a manual sewing machine, which is better than electric in villages where electricity can be out for days. In the town where I stayed, not only was the electricity out, but they had not had water for 10 days. Most rural villages have only central pumps to which people walk for miles with plastic yellow jerry cans to fill with water each day. Even small children 6 and older are seen carrying water.

Josephine would like to eventually own a boda-boda, or motorbike, and to buy an embroidery machine. But that is just a dream; for now she will use her loan to buy more material and embroidery for her business.

loans.use: Josephine plans to use her loan to buy more material and embroidery for her clothing design business.

loans.name: Azra

texts.en: I am married and a mother of two daughters. My daughters are small and do not attend school at the present. I would like to see my children attend and finish school so that they have a bright future. I operate a bangles business and my husband runs a general store. He sells all types of daily items including pulses, candies, soft drinks and milk etc. We need a loan for our store to expand its range of stock and therefore to increase our income. Please lend us $750 for this purpose.

loans.use: Expand general store

loans.name: Steven

texts.en: Steven is a 26 year old shop keeper in Lugazi. He is married with 4 children and he cares for one orphan. He has had his business for 7 years and has been a member of his lending group for 3 years. In his shop he sells salt, paraffin, sugar, maize flour, soap and cosmetics. Most retail stores sell similar items. In poor areas the needs of villagers are simple and there is very little ability for luxury items.  As a store owner you would not want to take a risk by adding a “new” item to your inventory, because the likelihood of it being sold would be small. So, one focuses on selling only the necessities. Being in a rural village, Steven also has room to do some farming. He owns 2 pigs. When you ask the people of Lugazi what animals they own, they always give you a count. Each animal has considerable value to them and the count is a way to let you know of their importance. Steven plans to add poultry to his farm, but for now he plans to use his loan to add the necessary items to his store to replenish his inventory.

loans.use: Steven plans to add more paraffin, dry goods, soap to his store inventory.

loans.name: Gulnaz

texts.en: I was born and brought up in Faisalabad, a city in Pakistan known for its textile industry, but moved to Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan after my marriage. I am a mother of four: two boys and two girls. My husband works at a nearby factory for a small salary and I am a seamstress. I create dresses for the women in my neighborhood and also sell them unstitched clothes. I buy fabrics from Lahore as well as Faisalabad for my business. I need a loan of $500 to invest in  high quality fabric and patterns so that I can prepare the latest clothes for the upcoming Eid ( a Muslim religious festival).

loans.use: Buy high quality fabric for the business

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
In the rural areas, people talk more about their farm animals than they do about their businesses. In many ways, they can count on their animals to keep them sustained more than they can count on their businesses. Much talk between neighbors is about the health and productivity of their animals. “How’s your cow?” “Not so well, she only gave 4 liters of milk yesterday. How’s your chicken?”

Along with animals, people always cultivate the soil and plant a few banana trees, sweet potatoes, beans, maize, cassava and even a little coffee, usually just enough for their own use. This year there has been a drought so the yields are quite small.

Florence has one adult cow and two calves. It would be rare to have someone have more than this in this rural area of Uganda, the plots of land are far too small. But Florence has a large plot and she even hopes to buy another cow. She has cross breeds which tend to be less prone to disease and give more milk.

Florence also sells new children’s and women’s clothing in the market. She has been selling clothing for 7 years, and has been a member of her lending group for two and half years. With her loan, she will buy more clothing to sell.

loans.use: Florence plans to use her loan to buy more clothing to sell.

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en: I am a widow with four children: three sons and one daughter. All of my children are above 18 and had to quit their school after primary grades due to lack of money to pay for their school fees. One of my sons makes embroidered clothes, the other one is a tailor and the youngest of all works in a local factory. I need a loan of $500 for my son who is a tailor. He operates his business in a rented shop and does well. He also sells unstitched cloth at his shop to his customers so that they do not have to go to far away markets for it. He has three workers to help him in the business. Now he wishes to expand his business further and buy cloth in bulk for which he requires a loan. He plans to save the extra profits for his sister’s marriage.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is the treasurer for her lending group in the village of Lugazi. She is 46, widowed with 7 children, and she cares for 2 orphans. She has what is referred to as a mobile business and is also referred to as a hawker. She sells children’s clothes, door nets (many people do not have doors to their homes, just nets) and second hand clothes. As a hawker, she carries her wares around markets, taxi parks, and other congested areas, selling only what she can carry.

Edith has been in this business for ten years and a member of her lending group for 9 years. To get her inventory, she will travel one and a half hours to Kampala. She will go to the market where she will buy bales of used clothing. Bales would be like a gunny sack full or a wired bundle of hundreds of items of used clothing. She is not allowed to inspect, so she must know her contact. She will load up the bale, often strapped on the back of a matatoo, or taxi van, and head home. There she will sort and hang her clothes on a pole and head out to sell “on the street” of her village.

As Edith is getting older, she dreams of one day having enough money to pay the rent for a store front so that she can operate out of one place. For now, she plans on using her loan to buy more bales to sell as a hawker.

loans.use: Edith plans to use her loan to purchase bales of used clothing to sell.

loans.name: Makhbuba

texts.en:
Makhbuba is a low income vulnerable woman. She is 39, married with three children and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Makhbuba and her husband (pictured) have a scant herd of milk cows and sell 60 liters of milk per day to the local milk processing shop and super market. The trade is good and Makhbuba can see that she could sell more milk. This requires more cattle in the herd and so Makhbuba decided to buy a calf to breed to increase monthly income. She applied for a $500 loan to Normicro's Saatli branch for the purpose to buy a calf and increase the number of cattle in her herd.

Note from Normicro Staff: Families the in Azeri countryside are usually male-dominated and, oftentimes, men do not allow people to take pictures of their wives. Looking after cows, harvesting, feeding stuff for cattle is done mainly by men yet the business is the wife's and the loan is requested by the wife.

loans.use: To buy a calf

loans.name: Saifullo

texts.en: Saifullo M. lives in Mastchokh; he is married and has 6 children. Saifullo M. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2006. Stable business and income helped to back old loans and to increase the new loan sum. He engages in business of livestock, livestock-raising and selling.  He would like to purchase a pedigree bull to increase his livestock. Also he plans to produce milk and sour products such as pasteurized milk, sour milk, sour cream and curd.  Mr. Saifullo M. requests a loan of US$1025 to buy the pedigree bull and to start sour milk production.

loans.use: to buy a pedigree bull and start sour milk production.

loans.name: Behzod

texts.en: C. Behzod is an active client of Microinvest.  He is not married and lives with his parents. His business is the trade of DVD and CD disks and his store is located in the Istaravshan district of Khujand,Tadjikistan.  Before he sold audio music tapes, by developing technology compelled him to change his goods to DVDs and CDs.  With a loan from Microinvest he could made the transition without any problem.  We can say that he is a punctual repayer of loans from our organization. As person he is very serious and responsible. He quickly reacts to changes of technology and always meets all client needs.  From Kiva he requests an additional loan to buy more blank DVD disks to record on them.

loans.use: Purchase of blank DVDs for business.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima K. lives in Mastchokh; she is married and has 3 children. She has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007 but is a serious client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedures.  Mrs. K. is in the business of rice selling. She has a direct supplier, which allows her to sell rice at a price lower than the bazaar price. She is very polite and has permanent clients who want to buy only from her. She is very experienced in the business.  Mrs. K. requests a loan for US$300 for business development. She wants to increase sales volume to increase family income which would allow her daughter to continue her education.

loans.use: for business development.

loans.name: Makhadlatif

texts.en: Makhadlatif L. lives in Mastchokh; he is married and has 3 children. He has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2005 and business stability allows him to increase the loan sum.  He is engages in the Oshkhona business (the national culinary). He prepares different kind of national courses using old traditional recipes. Having the Oshkhona he dreams to build a Chaikhona (from the old times, the resting place where you may try the national tea and culinary).Mr. Makhadlatif L. requests a loan a US$450 to expand the existing business wideness and develop the new one.

loans.use: To expand existing business and build new one.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Mrs. Seng N., 30, is a mother of three little children and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is a traditional doctor making and selling Khmer traditional medicine to the people in her area and typically makes around $2/day. Her husband is unemployed and he would like to work as a fisherman to help his household generate more additional income. Unfortunately, he faces a financial constraint. Mrs Seng hopes to take out the loan to purchase a boat, fishing net and other items for her husband’s fishery. She is confidential that her husband will make another source of income for her and her family. ( some of the little children in the picture are her neigbors' children and the rest are their children)

loans.use: To purchase a boat, fishing net and other items to operate a fishery business.

loans.name: Tahira

texts.en: I am a very ambitious entrepreneur. After my husband’s accident, when he had to quit his business due to serious injuries I became determined to make my business a success and provide for my five children. I make and sell blankets. I also contract women in my neighborhood to help me with the work. My husband obtains orders from the markets and then buys the necessary materials including cloth and threads etc for us to make blankets. I have being very good at my work and I make decent profit out of this business. Please lend me $675 to expand my business, because it is a high season and demand for blankets has risen sharply. I intend to save the extra profits for my daughter’s marriage who is already engaged.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Rauf

texts.en: Rauf is a lorry driver. He is 33, married with two children and lives  in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Rauf has been driving a lorry for 14 years. He is looking for credit so that he can make repairs to his vehicle, which is his main source of income.

loans.use: To repair lorry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: increase her business

loans.name: Latafet

texts.en: Latafet is a 32-year-old married woman . She is a farmer and lives with her family in Saatli, situated in the central part of Azerbaijan. She started her business in 1995, when she purchased one cow with money she had saved up. The work is hard but interesting and takes a lot of effort. Her husband helps her to  purchase calves, breed them and cut and sell them to the butcher at the local big market. At the same time, the salary is not enough to cover all family expenses. To increase the profit margin from the selling, Latafet has to invest some money to make her small herd bigger. This summer she applied for $500 to buy four calves.  She hopes eventually to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Sou

texts.en:
Mrs. Sou S., 32, lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works as a farmer growing a wide variety of vegetables on her farmland, making around $2.30/day from selling her outputs to her customers at a market. Her husband works as a laborer and generally earns about $3.60 per day, while three of her children are enrolled in school and another one is too young to go to school yet.
Mrs. Sou S. hopes this loan will help her purchase seeds to expand her crops and the leftover of the money is to buy a water pump machine and to dig a well to help water the crops.

loans.use: To purchase seeds to expand her crops and the leftover of the money is to buy a water pump machine and to dig a well so that in the future her crops to water the crops.

loans.name: Najjembe Group Loan

texts.en:
You may not think that selling yellow bananas in a country where bananas grow everywhere and cost next to nothing would be a wise business decision, but then you have never seen the sight along the one of a kind roadside venue on the main road from Kenya to Kampala where Nanono is in competition with a least three dozen other women who sell only one thing to passerbys: yellow bananas.

Here’s what happens. There is a constant stream of van taxis each carrying 14 passengers on this very busy and dangerous road. They all stop at this roadside pullover (the driver gets a free bunch of bananas for doing this). Immediately upon stopping, dozens of women attack the van with bunches of ripened bananas. They swarm around every window. The conductor, the man next to the sliding side door, opens it and bunches of banana are pressed into your face. You can buy a ripen bunch, say 14-20 in a bunch for 30 cents. The driver stops long enough to get his free bunch and enough for anyone to buy and off we go again down the road as the ladies back off and wait for the next taxi.

Now get this, Nanono who is 35, single with 6 children and cares for 4 orphans has been doing this for 15 years, supporting her family. She is the chairperson of the Najjembe Lending Group of which she has been a member for the past 7 years. Her portion of the loan will be about $175.00 which she will use to pay school fees for her children.

One side note regarding this group. Loans are disbursed to the group. Although there is not a lot of crime, the time of the loan disbursements can be risky due to the money involved. I asked the group if we could go outside to take the photo and I was told that they were afraid due to the fact that there had been a hold-up a couple of months earlier with another group loan.

loans.use: Nanono plans to use her portion of the group loan to pay her children's school fees.

loans.name: Gaflali

texts.en: Gaflali is a low-income vulnerable person. He is 45, married with four children and lives in the town of Saatli in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Gaflali rents a small shop in Saatli town and sells food. The business is very successful and needs some investments to increase the daily turnover. But Gaflali has no collateral to apply to the commercial banks. That's why he applied to Normicro Saatli branch for a $500 loan. This credit could let him buy and sell a bigger amount of goods and provide better the necessities of life for his children.

loans.use: To increase variety of business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy parts for his shop

loans.name: Thi Huong

texts.vi:
Mrs Huong is thirty years old and she has two children in the first grade. Her husband is Mr. Dung who is the city chief police. He works during the week and helps with the family business during the weekend. Mrs. Huong is mainly in charge of managing the business. She sells flowers, fashion hats and eyes glasses. Her store is located downtown so it is very advantageous. She requests a loan of US$150.00 to buy more flowers to service the retail stores and weddings. Monthly revenue will help her pay it back easily and she likes the idea of term payment since that will reduce the burden.

Translate from Vietnamese by Hien T. Lam, KIVA volunteer.

Chị Hương 30 tuổi, chị có 2 con nhỏ đang đi học cấp 1. Chồng chị là anh Dũng, làm trưởng công an của Thị trấn. Anh đi làm việc cả ngày nên chỉ giúp chị được vào ngày nghỉ cuối tuần. Mọi việc kinh doanh chủ yếu chỉ một mình chị đảm nhiệm. Chị kinh doanh hoa tươi, kính và mũ thời trang. Cửa hàng của chị ở trung tâm nên việc kinh doanh rất thuận lợi. Chị vay vốn để lấy thêm hoa tươi về bán, chị làm chủ yếu cho các đám cưới và bán lẻ. Thu nhập hàng ngày giúp chị có khả năng trả vốn dễ dàng hơn. Chị rất thích được trả dần vì như thế sẽ giảm gánh nặng cho chị.

loans.use: To purchase flowers for sales

loans.name: Thi Lan

texts.vi:
Ms Lan is sixty years old. She has retired and actually lives on her monthly pension. Her family has a bamboo business since twenty years ago. Her business is the monopoly in the whole city so it is very advantageous. She has never borrowed from anyone but when she heard about the BinhMinh loan program that is very simple, fast and most importantly, there is no need for collateral, she applied right away. She requests for a loan of US$150.00 to buy more bamboo and will use the revenue from this business to repay it.

Translate from Vietnamese by Hien T. Lam, KIVA volunteer.

Bà Lan 60 tuổi, bà là công nhân về hưu và được hưởng lương hưu hàng tháng. Hiện tại gia đình bà đang kinh doanh tre, nứa. Đây là nghề kinh doanh của gia đình bà, tính đến nay đã được 20 năm. Cả thị trấn hiện nay chỉ có duy nhất nhà bà là kinh doanh mặt hàng này nên khá thuận lợi. Bà chưa từng tham gia vay vốn ở đâu đến khi biết đến chương trình cho vay vốn Binhminh thì bà đã đăng ký vay ngay vì thủ tục rất đơn giản, nhanh gọn và quan trọng nhất là bà không cần phải thế chấp gì cả. Bà vay vốn về để mua thêm tre về bán và sẽ sử dụng thu nhập có được từ công việc này để hoàn trả vốn vay.

loans.use: To purchase bamboo for sale

loans.name: Victoria Women's Lending Group

texts.en:
Let’s all move to Kiyinde. Resting on the slopes of Lake Victoria, the source of the Nile, at an elevation of about 1,000 meters with gentle breezes coming off the lake, this fishing village, or landing as it referred to, is a jewel of tranquility. Here the Victoria Women’s Lending Group meets weekly. This sleepy village with views of a multitude of islands can only be reached by a one hour drive on very rutted roads. As you come into town you are taken back by its beauty and its babies. If, as I’m told, Uganda has one of the highest birthrates in the world, then Kiyinde is certainly doing its fair share in keeping that statistic. Remote villages tend to have high birthrates.

Fishing is the main industry in Kiyinde and I think the men go fishing and the women run the place. That was certainly the feeling as I met with this dynamic group of women who are members of the Victoria Lending Group. They are a joy to be around. As we walked through the streets, they all command a strong presence of hospitality and openness.

Ayisna is the chairperson and she owns a small grocery where she sells sugar, salt, maize flour, along with soft drinks and personal hygiene items. She is widowed and has 10 children and she cares for 4 orphans. With her loan she plans to add to her inventory at her store. She would eventually buy a cow and hopes to educate her children to the university level.

loans.use: Ayisna plans to use her loan to buy more dry goods and staples for her grocery store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increase cereal stock

loans.name: Aslon

texts.en:
Aslon J. is engaged in trade for over 13 years.  He is married and has three children.  During the USSR he worked in a collective farm as an agronomist.  Now he is a pensioner and invalid but his disability pension is not enough for supporting a family.  His elder son is in Russia and he sends money but conditions become more expensive every day.   Aslon decided to start a business with his experience farming.  He rented a trade place in the food market in Istaravshan, Tadjikistan.  He has increased his product selection and has attracted many clients.  He always try to have different goods and changes his inventory according to client needs.
When he heard about KIVA program he decided to take part in it.  He requests a loan to buy goods in bulk so that his products will be cheaper in price.

loans.use: To buy his goods in bulk.

loans.name: Thi Xuyen

texts.vi:
Mrs Xuyen is 40 years old and she has two school age children. Her family owns a bridal shop and studio at Bac Ninh for several years. Her store provides dress-up service for the brides, wedding clothes and photography on various occasions. She has worked very hard to get to the point where she is now. She has borrowed from the local bank where she lives. After knowing about the loan program Binh Minh, she applied and was initially given a maximum credit of VND2,600,000. She requests for a loan of $US150.00 to buy more studio equipments and wedding gowns.

Translate from Vietnamese by Hien T. Lam, KIVA volunteer.

Chị Xuyên 40 tuổi, có 2 con nhỏ đang đi học. Gia đình chị mở ảnh viện áo cưới (cửa hàng áo cưới có kèm theo dịch vụ chụp ảnh) ở phố Chờ, Bắc Ninh đã nhiều năm nay. Cửa hàng chị cung cấp các dịch vụ áo cưới, trang điểm cô dâu và chụp ảnh các loại. Để xây dựng được cửa hàng như ngày nay, chị đã trải qua rất nhiều khó khăn và chị cũng đã từng tham gia vay vốn của ngân hàng nơi chị sinh sống. Khi biết đến chương trình tài chính vi mô Binhminh, chị đã đăng ký vay và bước đầu được duyệt ở mức là VND2,006,000 để mua thêm phụ trang cho một số mẫu áo cưới và các thiết bị về ảnh.

loans.use: To purchase photographic equipment
